Title: Page 1
AltTitle.other: The designer goes to source material|~|Advice to young designers and business women
Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten is "From 'Style' - Jan. '77 - Toronto, Canada".  This article discusses Cashin's views on source material.  Cashin wrote the piece and says that source material, for the designer, is a lifetime study of the world around us-- and living.  She describes her way of viewing the world and how fun it can be.  The article continues discussing Cashin's view of the world and how she finds sources for her work.  The article is continued in uclamss_440_b130_002a.

Title: Page 28a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin's playful side!
Description.note: One clipping.  An advertisement for Bonnie Cashin's playful clothes at Neiman Marcus. Prices range from $13.95 to $49.95.  Sketches in the advertisement include a romper playsuit, a beach parka with an eye-shadow sunbonnet, a polka dot sunsuit (with curved high tide shorts and separate camisole), and Cashin's famous "Station Wagon" raincoat with a matching purse skirt.  (Same clipping in uclamss_440_b114_011b).

Subject: skirts (garments)|~|cashmere (wool)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1960-1970|~|leather|~|fur|~|tights (opaque stockings)|~|shirts|~|hats

Title: Page 13b
AltTitle.other: The fashion scene begins to catch up with Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: One clipping.  From the New York Post, May 16, 1968.  Article discussing Bonnie Cashin, her design inspirations, and her pieces in the Body Covering exhibition at The Museum of Contemporary Crafts.  Cashin is described as a nature girl and an intellectual.  Many of Cashin's pieces are described, particulary her tweed and leather pieces.  A variety of Cashin designs are shown.  In sketch form there is a quilted leather cape over a leather skirt, cashmere tights, and a hood-or-collar sweater.  In photograph form there is a leather parabola coat, a fur lamb skirt with a cashmere shirt, a leather-trimmed robin red canvas cape, skirt, and a cashmere shirt.

Title: Page 21a
AltTitle.other: The country shop|~|Swirl, girl|~|Coty awards
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from the Chicago Tribune, July 29, 1968.  This clipping discusses Cashin's coats.  Shown in a photograph are two suede (?) coats.  In the photograph there is also a woman in a cotton canvas coat lined with cotton-backed acrylic pile, lavishly collared with natural raccoon, belted and edged in supple leather.  It costs $160.  The second clipping has handwritten on the bottom of the clipping "Philadelphia Inquirer - Sept. /68".  This clipping is an advertisement for Cashin's designs at Nan Duskin Young Set.  Shown is a drawing of a vast, circling fleece cape, generously collared and clasped with leather, then flung over a stove-pipe collared stripe jersey dress.  The third clipping is from The New York Times, June 21, 1968.  This clipping has the sections mentioning Cashin bracketed in pen. The article discusses the 1968 Coty American Fashion Critics Awards.

Name.subject: Vogue (Magazine)
Title: Page 26b
AltTitle.other: Raccoon and suede|~|The yoked loose - hemmed coat
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first has handwritten below "Vogue 8 / 68".  This clipping shows a woman in a yoked loose-hemmed coat in dark grey with black leather collar, black leather yoke-wrist-and-hem bands, pluse a big fluff of muff and black leather boots.  It is Cashin for Philip Sills and made of Acrilan and Dynel pile.  It costs $160.  The second clipping has handwritten below "Vogue Sept 1/ 68".  This clipping shows a high-waisted to (tunic?) of caramel suede, raccoon at the neck and raccoon from waist to hem.  It is by Cashin for Philip Sills.  The third clipping shows a woman in a dress and sunglasses (not by Cashin?).  She also wears a belt and a bag by Bonnie Cashin for Coach Leatherware.  The bag and belt look like a fanny pack.

Title: Page 33b
AltTitle.other: Jogging in fashion|~|Fashion|~|The "in" people jog fashionably
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first clipping (Chicago Tribune, October 15, 1968) discusses the new trend of jogging.  The article talks about Bonnie Cashin's gray and crushed raspberry cashmere hooded sweatsuit.  There are also orange trackshoes designed by Cashin to go with the sweatsuit.The second clipping (Oakland Tribune, Dec. 19, 196?) asks Cashin what she would want for Christmas.  She responds: "leather bloomers in 12 different colors with cummerbunds to match, because the boys like them."The third clipping (Country Life, October 17, 1968) showcases a tunic, trousers, cashmere hooded sweater, and raccoon hat by Cashin.The fourth clipping discusses Cashin's jogging sweatsuit design.

Title: Page 38a
AltTitle.other: So who wears underwear?|~|It all spells femininity|~|Dressing the non show-offs|~|Sharpe on color
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first is from Women's Wear Daily, January 22, 1969.  This article discusses Dr. Deborah Sharpe's treatment of color as a science.  There is a note of "Ha" written by the quotation "We had color five years ago that was chaotic."  Cashin's name is also underlined and the section on Cashin is bracketed in pen.  Cashin is said to be an artist.  The second clipping is from The Christian Science Monitor, February 17, 1969.  This article discusses Cashin's bloomer dress that looks soft and smart.  The dress comes in wool jersey with V-neck, sleeveles, and can be worn as a jumper with skinny sweater or blouse.  The dress is in Cashin's line for Philip Sills.  The third clipping has handwritten above "London" and is from The Lady, January 30, 1969.  This article talks about countrywomen versus show-offs.  Cashin is discussed, in terms of countrywomen.  The fourth clipping is from The Sunday Express London, January 19, 1969 [not totally sure on date, hard to read].  "London" is handwritten next to the drawing.  The clipping women's way of dressing in layers and wearing tights instead of underwear.  Cashin is discussed in terms of designing for dressing in layers.

Subject: suits (main garments)|~|skirts (garments)|~|cardigans|~|capes (outerwear)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1960-1970|~|tweed|~|dresses (garments)|~|leather|~|shoulder bags|~|plaids|~|headcloths (headgear)|~|pleats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 42a
AltTitle.other: Tweed, leather come on strong in early Spring fashions|~|The Bonnie Cashin collection|~|Cashin... in advance
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from The Sacramento Bee, February 6, 1969.  This article discusses Cashin's Spring fashions.  There are four photographs in this clipping.  These photographs show: a wooly plaid skirt suit with a pleated skirt and a cardigan [? jacket?]; a modified trench coat of leather in a color called mushroom; a full-circle cape of imported Irish tweed with a stand-up black leather collar tied with spaghetti thin strips, a dress, and a headwrap; and a coat for all seasons, half in wool and half in pheasant blue leather.  The second clipping is an advertisement for Cashin at Liberty's.  Handwritten is "London Times Apr/69".  There is a drawing of a checked canvas showerproof coat bound inside with kid leather.  The coat has giant pockets and hardware fastenings.  It is availabe in toffee, pheasant, and black on white and costs 69 pounds.  There are also leather knickerbockers in matching colors (38 pounds), a jellybag hat in all Cashin colors (5 pounds), and a harness leather bag in black, toffee, walnut, geranium (42 pounds).  The third clipping has handwritten below "W.W.D. 2/7/69".  It may be 3/7/69, it's slightly illegible.  This clipping shows a drawing of a coat that wraps around like a capelet or opens up like a big pocket sleeve.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 2b
AltTitle.other: Canvas poncho brown as Irish peat|~|This is the way we walk in rain
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first clipping is on top of a cut out of the cover of Vogue from October 15.  Handwritten is "1969".  The first clipping shows a man and a woman ("Anjelica").  Anjelica wears a hooded canvas coat that closes with hardware.  The coat is beige and lined in fake fur pile.  It is by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills.  She also wears pants.  The second clipping wears a canvas poncho brown as Irish peat shining with leather at every turn over a tweedy brown sweater that wears its leather on its sleeve.  The poncho is by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills and costs about $125.

AltTitle.other: Vogue
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first has "Vogue" handwritten in the middle of the top of the clipping.  There is a photograph of a man in a vest, pants, and a blouse-like shirt.  There is a woman in a quilted (?) skirt over a lace skirt, a blouse-like shirt, and a short vest (?).  The second clipping has handwritten in the top left corner "Vogue Aug 1 /69".  There is a woman ("Penelope") in a brown suede shirtdress with three rows of fringe over narrow suede pants with more fringe.  The outfit is by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills.

AltTitle.other: Designer views hemline hassle as gimmick|~|From Bonnie Cashin, cheerful colors|~|The boots & the bags
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first article (The Milwaukee Journal, April 19, 1970) discusses Bonnie Cashin's opinions on hemlines.  There is a handwritten note correcting the article. The article claims that Cashin prefers hemlines "two inches below the knee." The note states "I said above." There is an image of Bonnie Cashin in a coat with a shoulder bag.The second clipping (N.Y. Post, November 17, 1970) discusses Cashin's new boots and bag lines for Coach. There is an image of a shoulder bag.The third clipping (Times, November 13, 1970) discusses the prevalence of layering in Cashin's Spring collection for Philip Sills. There are two photographs. One shows a minidress over a skirt, over another skirt, over pants. The second photograph shows a cape over a maxidress.

AltTitle.other: Mr. Harold Macmillian can get away with baggy tweeds for shooting.|~|Bonnie Cashin does a beautiful little mauve suede suit for Phillip Sills
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (Vogue, February 1, 1971) features a large color image of a mauve suede Inverness coat.  It is part of a suit.  It is $295. The second clipping (Harpers & Queen, July 1971) features an image of a woman wearing a Bonnie Cashin tweed coat while hunting.  The coat is from the Bonnie Cashin Room in London.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|leather|~|fur|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 4a
AltTitle.other: Fall furs: the designers' touch|~|Bonnie Cashin for H.B.A.
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first (Women's Wear Daily, June 5, 1974) discusses Cashin's fall fur collection for H.B.A. Cashin designed the collection for "the non-fur customer who dosen't go into fur departments."  Her collection includes capes, shirts, coats, and skirts.  There are four photographs with the article.  The first shows a double-duty reversed patchwork cape in lamb fur.  The cape also works as a skirt.  The second photo shows a robe/poncho/cape in skunk fur.  The third photo is of a Noh coat in Canadian lynx.  The four photo is a hooded bubble jacket in Western wildcat.  The second, third, and fourth clippings are advertisements for Bonnie Cashin for H.B.A.  In one photo, a woman wears the reversible lamb coat.  In the second, a raccoon cape.  In the third, the Noh coat in Canadian lynx.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|skirts (garments)|~|coatdresses|~|jackets (garments)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|stripes|~|trousers|~|fur|~|plaids
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 4b
AltTitle.other: Talk about clothes: Cashin's treasures|~|Cashin in on furs
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first (N.Y. Post, Nov. 8, 1974) discusses the strength of Bonnie Cashin's designs for Philip Sills.  This article features four photographs of Bonnie Cashin designs on women.  These photographs show off: an awning-striped wool jersey jacket, white leather pants ("just wipe clean with a bit of ivory soap"), leather many-occasion suit with a tiered skirt, sheer tweed plaid coat dress with burnoose sleeves, white leather hip-length "chopper" jacket, and a chiffon tweed pleated ballet length skirt.  The second (New York Post, Oct. 2, 1974) discusses Cashin's fur collection for H.B.A. Furs.  There is a photograph of a woman in a Cashin fur, and also a hood and trousers.  The third clipping (W.W., Apr. 19, 1974) also discusses Cashin's H.B.A. Fur line.  Cashin describes the collection as "for the more intellectual woman and for the girl who hasn't been very interested in furs--rather the individual look of a unique wool or leather."

Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (Newsday's Magazine for Long Island, January 6, 1974) discusses Mrs. John R. (Tex) McCrary of Manhasset, of the radio show "Tex and Jinx," and her affinity for Cashin clothes.  She is shown in four Cashin ensembles.  The items she wears include: a turtleneck sweater and matching skirt; a leather-trimmed, camel-colored jersey suit, and a hood; a canvas coat with pile lining and a raccoon collar, with plaid trousers; and a "No-Coat" sweater.  The second clipping (1974) features a drawing of Cashin's Noh Coat.  The clipping is an advertisement for Kramer's.

AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin|~|Bonnie coup|~|Bonnie Cashin for HBA|~|Mink: relatively a bargain|~|Fashion overture '74
Description.note: Five clippings.  The first is magenta and green and says "Fashion Overture '74".  The second clipping has handwritten on the right "Dec./74" and a photoraph of a woman in a Bonnie Cashin camel-color mink bubble jacket collared and cuffed in mohair knit for HBA.  THe third clipping is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin at B. Altman & Co.  There is a drawing of a woman in a natural calfskin topper, with cardigan edges/elbow patches tone-matched in stitched leather.  It costs $695.  The fourth clipping is a brief article noting that B. Altman has cornered the fur collection that won the American Fashion Designers Award for Bonnie Cashin.  The fifth clipping discusses Bonnie Cashin for HBA, very briefly.

Title: Page 7a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin's lynx coat kicks off the fall fur story
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Feminique section of the Chicago Tribune, July 8, 1974.  There is a photograph of a woman in Bonnie Cashin’s lynx coat. Cashin's Noh silhouette design exemplifies the trend on Seventh Avenue—a new, roomy, sOft shaping. The coat, tied in front with a narrow leather belt, is lined in sandy wool jersey for practical warmth.

Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from "Gossip!  Canada's Magazine for the Carriage Trade" from February 1974. There is a photograph of a woman in a suede suit in "natural."  She also wears a beret and has a soft leather purse.  The second clipping has "1974" handwritten in the bottom right corner.  There is also a fair amount of handwritten notes around a sketch of 3 outfits (sweater, shirt, skirt, pants).  Accompanying these notes is a photograph of a woman in a striped coat, a turtleneck, and pants. The third clipping is (handwritten:) from the New York Times, March 3, 1974.  There is a photograph of a glove with a red and white checker print with a white heart in the center of the palm.

Clipping is an advertisement for informal modeling of Cashin's fashions at Saks Fifth Avenue.  There is a photograph of a woman in a Cashin turban, loose-fitting button down blouse, and bell-bottoms.

Title: Page 9b
AltTitle.other: Cashin: a wrap session
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from the New York Post, March 21, 1975.  Article from Ruth Preston's column "Talk About Clothes."  The article discusses Cashin's new Spring furs and other designs.  There is a photograph of a woman in a H.B.A. Tobacco calfskin bordered in stitched leather wrapped topper/jacket.  She also wears a sweater with a hood.  There is an additional photograph of a woman in a white lamb pants suit with a headcloth.  The second clipping from (handwritten:) "W.w. May 27/75" (Women's Wear?) shows a drawing of a woman in a mink coat with a leather tie.  She also wears a hood.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: jackets (garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|trousers|~|fur|~|mackinaws
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 10a
AltTitle.other: A patch of Spring|~|Cashin wraps it up|~|Bonnie Cashin's easy tote|~|Fall furs: the big looks
Description.note: Five clippings.  First clipping has a photograph of a woman's legs in pants, also holding a bag (Bonnie Cashin's easy tote).  Handwritten on top left is "WW. Nov./74."  Possibly Women's Wear?  The second clipping has "N.Y. Post July 1/75" handwritten in top right corner.  There is an article discussing Bonnie Cashin's new collection for H.B.A. Furs.  There are three photographs.  They show: a half-cape-half-coat Kabuki Noh coat in ranch mink; a tweedy knit and beige nutria jacket; and a double-breasted mink coat in 35-inch length.  The third clipping is a very brief article about Cashin's fur collection.  Between this clipping and the fourth clipping is handwritten "W.W. June 10/75."  It is unclear which article (both?) this note refers to.  The fourth clipping shows three photographs of Cashin's fur coats.  They include: a short-sleeve lynx jacke; a furry coat with Lakoda seal top and sleeves and fisher-dyed raccoon skirt and trim; and a long fur coat.  The fifth clipping has "Feb 18/75 W.W." handwritten on the bottom left.  There is a drawing of a woman in a jacket with mink sides and leather trim, sash, and elbow patches.

Title: Page 10b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin for HBA|~|If you don't want to look like everyone else in mink, buy a mink that doesn't look like everyone else's.
Description.note: Five clippings.  The first has handwritten above it "New Yorker May 12/75."  The clipping is an advertisement for Cashin at EMBA.  There is a photograph of a woman in an American mink jacket.  The second clipping has handwritten below "Boston Sunday Globe - Sept. 7/75."  There is a photograph of a woman in a raccoon cape lined in soft jersey and is reversible.  The third clipping is a photograph of Cashin and a man.  Below is written "Cashin" and "Himmelfarb."  The fourth clipping is an advertisement for Cashin furs for HBA.  There is a photograph of a woman ina Canadian coyote coat.  Handwritten below is "NY. Times."  THe fifth clipping is another advertisement for Bonnie Cashin for HBA.  There is a photograph of a woman in a natural ranch mink edged in white mink jacket and fur stole.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|stoles (outerwear)|~|jackets (garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|vests (garments)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|trousers|~|fur
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 11a
AltTitle.other: Faced with restrictions, furriers show they can be creative|~|A tally-ho! of the newest things in fur|~|Necking|~|Bonnie Cashin for HBA
Description.note: Five clippings.  The first is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin for HBA.  There is a photograph of a woman in a Canadian Lynx Noh coat.  She also wears a hood and pants.  The second clipping has "Daily News June 13/75" handwritten in the top right corner.  There is an article discussing Cashin's luxury furs for HBA.  The furs are called "long term investments."  Cashin's name is underlined in red (twice in the article) and there is a red "x" in the bottom right corner of the accompanying drawing.  The drawing depicts a vest under a wide cape with a hood.  The third clipping is a drawing of a woman in a fur jacket, with a fur stole, and a headcloth.  The fourth clipping is an article with an accompanying photograph.  Handwritten below the article is "N.Y. Times /75."  The article discusses conservationists and furriers, and the restrictions placed on furriers.  There is a photograph of a lamb pants suit ($2,500) and a hat with a tie beneath the chin.  The fifth clipping is a photograph of a fur jacket, and a fur scarf.  The woman also wears a heacloth and trousers.  Written above the caption is "W.W. July 8/75."

She also wears a hood and a sweater.  Below the photograph is handwritten "W Sept. 20 /74." The second clipping is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin for HBA fur corporation.  There is a photograph of a woman in a natural beige nutria fur coat.  She also wears a hat, a hood, gloves, and trousers.  On the left hand side of the clipping in pencil is written "Times Nov 9/75."

The second clipping is an advertisement for Cashin's new station wagon jacket at Lord & Taylor.  The jacket has toggles and a fur collar.

Title: Page 12b
AltTitle.other: Furs for Fall: at those prices, they'd better be marvelous|~|Bonnie Cashin|~|The cosmopolitan quilties
Description.note: Three clippings.  Below the first says handwritten below "N.Y. Times June 3/74."  There is an article discussing Cashin's fur designs and their merits.  There is a photograph of a fur Noh coat, a close-fitting hat/headgear, and sunglasses. The second clipping has handwritten in the bottom left corner "W.W. May 8/74."  There is short article discussing Bonnie Cashin's collection for Phillip Sills.  The article praises the slim fit of Cashin's designs, however expresses concern over the length of the skirts.  Photographs of several designs accompany the article including: a slim brown suede coat with raccoon collar; a rust and white check double faced wool coat; a slimmed down bubble suit; a beige and white tweed suit with leather yoked jacket; and a slim tweed coat over the brown shell and skirt.  The third clipping has "W.W. May 18/74" written on it.  There is a drawing of woman in a quilted Noh coat over matching sunflower-yellow pants with leather trim.

The two Cashin designs are a black and white poncho made of American skunk, and the other is a tawny natural American lynx cape.  The women also wear hoods and hats.  The second clipping shows a picture of a woman in a hand-knit nubby and slubby wool tweed sleeveless sweater.

Title: Page 14a
AltTitle.other: Saks Fifth Avenue: celebrating fifty years of fashion|~|Have the inimitable Bonnie Cashin look|~|Nordstrom presents Bonnie Cashin designs
Description.note: Six clippings.  The first is a drawing (watercolor?) of two women.  On the bottom is handwritten "W. May 17/74".  One woman wears a loose cardigan coat in thick Scottish tweed traced in leather and with a matching scarf.  All by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills.  The second clipping is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin designs at Nordstrom.  There is a drawing of a woman in a hood, jacket, and skirt.  The third clipping is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin's new fall line of Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills at Lipmans.  There is a drawing of a woman in a jacket, skirt, and hat.  The fourth clipping is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin's wine toast for Saks Fifth Avenue in honor of Saks' fiftieth anniversary.  The fifth clipping is an advertisement for Cashin's Fall Collection at I. Magnin in San Francisco.  The sixth clipping is a photograph of a woman in a natural dark ranch mink gills with natural white flecks.  It costs $950 and is at I. Magnin.  The woman also wears a hood.

Subject: skirts (garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|ponchos|~|capes (outerwear)|~|shorts (garments)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|leather|~|fur|~|kimonos|~|knapsacks
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 14b
AltTitle.other: Can you cape this?  That's Fall's question|~|Look beyond Summer to the chill of Fall-- and the fun of capes
Description.abstract: Four clippings.  The first (handwritten: "Nov. 14/74") shows the back of a woman in Cashin shorts, boots (?), hooded sweater, and knapsack.  The second (The New York Times.  Handwritten: "May 4/74") shows a Cashin cape in fluffy navy and gold plaid over a navy jersey hooded dress.  The accompanying article discusses capes (including their utility).  The third clipping (handwritten: "WW Jun.11/74") shows four Cashin outfits in a fashion show: reversible patchwork lamb skirt/toga; lynx Noh coat; skunk poncho; and hooded fur bubble coat.  The fourth clipping has a brief article about capes accompanying a Cashin sketch of a mohair kimono jacket and quilted leather skirt.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: jackets (garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|fur|~|hats|~|headcloths (headgear)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 15a
AltTitle.other: Bicentennial spirit at the Smithsonian: a history of clothing|~|Don't ask why-- just cover your mink; reverse your fox
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (source and date unknown), has an article about Cashin's fur designs.  Cashin's adeptness at designing with fur is discussed in detail.  There are also several photographs and sketches of Cashin's designs.  The sketches show women in turtleneck sweaters with headcloths, coats, and jackets.  The photographs show women in fur coats and capes (including raccoon, mink, and feathered badger).  The women also wear hats, hoods, and turtleneck sweaters.  The second clipping is from The New York Times, September 21, 1974.  This clipping features an article about a bicentennial exhibition at the Smithsonian about the history of clothing in the US.  There is a photograph of Cashin viewing the exhibition in a headcloth and a dress.

Title: Page 15b
AltTitle.other: For 1974, no-nonsense designs dominate the fur collections.|~|The looks that last|~|For day or night, pants are a way of life|~|Lipmans welcomes Bonnie Cashin furs to Portland with a special showing
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first says handwritten below "Times May 30/74."  There is a brief article discussing new voluminous designs.  There is a photograph of a woman in a bloused top, knickers, a turtleneck, and a close-fitting hat.  The second clipping has handwritten on it "The Plain Dealer May 8/74."  Bonnie Cashin's name is circled in red.  There is an article discussing ponchos, capes, and blankets by Cashin.  There is an accompanying photograph of a cape in brushed wool blanket plaid.  The third clipping is an advertisement for Lipmans in Portland, Oregon.  On the bottom is handwritten "The Sunday Oregonian, October 13, 1974."  There is a drawing of a woman in a raccoon and leather jacket ($1595).  The fourth clipping has handwritten in the top left corner "Chic. Trib. July 8/74."  This clipping has an article discussing the new more rugged looks by designers.  Cashin is mentioned in regard to her fur designs.  There is an accompanying photograph of a reverse lambskin coat that creates a stained glass effect.  She also wears a hat and a hood.

Subject: skirts (garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|cardigans|~|capes (outerwear)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|fur|~|knickerbockers|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 19b
AltTitle.other: In the Cashin fashion
Description.note: One clipping.  From The Plain Dealer, August 25, 1974.  Article discusses the ideal Cashin customer.  There is a list of "qualifications" for potential Cashin buyers.  Five photographs of Cashin's fashions accompany the article.  The first photograph features a Persian lamb wrap skirt that reverses; a hooded raccoon cape lined in red jersey; and a wildcat bubble jacket (all from Cashin's fur collection for H.B.A.).  The second photograph features a cashmere bi-color tube in natural and white (from Cashin's Knittery line); a hooded tweed "thing" as Cashin calls it; and a teal jersey tube (from the Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills collection).  The third photograph shows a leather bicycle jacket with a built-in back pack and leather knickerbockers.  The fourth photograph shows a swashbuckling cape in a brushed mohair blanket plaid of camel and navy above a hooded camel jersey dress.  The fifth photograph shows a black and white nubby wool Noh coat for Cashin's Knittery collection.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 20a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin|~|Creative Cashin is talent scouting|~|Fashion overture is Sept. 11
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from The Cleveland Press, August 30, 1974.  There is an article discussing the timelessness of Cashin's designs.  There is also a discussion of the Cleveland Orchestra Women's Committee and Halle's Fashion Overture '74-- luncheon and cocktail dinner shows featuring Bonnie Cashin in person plus the Fall collections of top American and European designers.  Also discusses the donation of some Cashins to the Western Reserve Historical Society.  There are two accompanying photographs: one of a woman in a 1963 purple tweed suit and one of a woman in a 1965 suede coat and a 1974 jersey sheath.  The second clipping discusses Cashin's idea of creating a cottage industry in the United States.  There is a photograph of Cashin in a headcloth and a knitted cardigan.  Handwritten below the article is "Plain Dealer Sept. 12/74."  The third clipping is an advertisement for Saks Fifth Avenue in Beverly Hills.  There is a drawing of a big top in acrylic and wool jersey ($120) over feather pants $165.  Handwritten in the bottom right corner is "LA Times 2/4/74."

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|skirts (garments)|~|scarves (costume accessories)|~|jackets (garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|mohair|~|tweed|~|trousers|~|gloves|~|cowl neck collar|~|hats|~|chemise dresses|~|turnlocks (fasteners)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 20b
AltTitle.other: A poncho cape|~|Cleanly cut lines classic
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from the Spokane Daily Chronicle, September 3, 1974.  There is an article discussing Cashin's unstructured, casual designs.  There are two photographs of a loose unstructured dresses, one with a hooded cowl neck topped by an open-front suede coat, and a jersey dress with suede sleeves and bodice.  The second clipping has handwritten in the bottom right corner "Milwaukee Sentinel Jul. 10/74."  There is a photograph of a woman in a poncho cape of Donegal tweed with leather trim.  There is a matching skirt suit, with a jacket and box pleated skirt.  The third clipping is from July 28, 1974, source unknown.  There is a photograph of two women in mohair with leather big-little and big-long coats.  The big-little coat (a short, but full swing jacket) is in a winter-white tone called sandstone and traced with leather.  The big-long coat (a long, full coat) has a yoked front and back with wind-resistant splashes of sandstone leather.  Front is battened down with hardward [turnlock / turnscrew] closures.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|shawls |~|ponchos|~|hoods (headgear)|~|tweed|~|stripes|~|burnouses|~|gloves|~|skullcaps (caps)|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 21a
AltTitle.other: Drama--done with simplicity|~|Desert flair
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (The Cleveland Press [Women's section], September 3, 1974) has a story about the drama and simplicity of Cashin's fall designs.  Cashin describes her fashions as "workable, enduring, uncommon, pleasurable to the eye and a delight to touch."  There are two photographs accompanying the article.  THe first shows what Cashin calls her "Mother Superior" dress: a striped jersey with a yoked waist and maxiskirt.  The matching shawl can be worn on the shoulders.  The other photograph shows a tweed suit with leather and a matching poncho.  This woman is also wearing sunglasses.  The second clipping (S.F. Examiner) talks about djellabas and caftans from Morocco and Tunisia as inspiration for designers.  There is a photograph of Cashin's wool knit burnoose in gold, salmon, and white stripes trimmed and belted in gold suede.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|skirts (garments)--1970-1980|~|ombré|~|fur|~|turbans|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 21b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin|~|Fashion is full of fun
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (The Plain Dealer, Sept. 12, 1974) discusses the Fashion Overture '74 planned by the Women's Committee of the Cleveland Orchestra.  The theme of the show was a European circus.  Cashin featured prominently in the show.  Several photographs of attendees as well as models.  Cashin is pictured as well.  Her designs featured in the images are a lynx fur coat, a ombred blue chiffon dress, a rose matte jersey top, and a red and gold plaid brushed mohair skirt.  The second clipping (1974) is an advertisement for the Carriage Shop.  There is a Cashin sketch of a coat.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|skirts (garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|tweed|~|stripes|~|leather|~|sweaters|~|plaids|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 23b
AltTitle.other: Talk about clothes: the modern heirloom|~|Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first (W.W., Nov. 7, 1974) discusses the silhouettes of Cashin's collection for Philip Sills.  The four outfits shown include: a leather-bound striped jersey dress; a tan  jacket and dress with tiered leather skirt; a tweed suit with a burnoose sleeve; and a suede and flannel jacket with a soft flannel BigSkirt.  The second clipping (New York Post, May 3, 1974) discusses Cashin's collection.  Photographs of the "newsmakers" of the collection are shown: "Tiny Turquoise" plaid jacket over turquoise suede pants; a leather-topped tweed suit; and a leather-edged tweed capey jacket.  The third clipping is cut from a larger article in an unknown source.  The clipping speaks of Cashin's talent.  The fourth clipping (N.Y. Times, Feb. 18, 1974) is about Cashin's use of linen and cotton in Spring and Summer clothing.  There is also information about her work with The Knittery.  There is a photograph of a woman in one of her knitted linen smocks with lacy open stitches.

Title: Page 24b
AltTitle.other: The elegant solution|~|Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first (Harper's Bazaar, 1974) is a photograph of a woman's face wearing a Cashin hat (perhaps with zebra print above the brim?) and turtleneck sweater.  She is also wearing Bernard Kayman glasses.  The second clipping (W., 1974) has a brief caption describing the photograph of an unlined suit in coral suede with a tiered skirt and short jacket.  The woman is also wearing a matching hood.  The third clipping (American Fabrics Magazine, 1974) is an essay by Cashin about the mathematical phrase "the elegant solution" applied to fashion and design.

Title: Page 25b
AltTitle.other: How Americans dressed for 200 years
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first discusses an exhibition at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of History & Technology called "Suiting Everyone."  The exhibit features clothing from 200 years of American clothing.  Cashin is not mentioned in this article.  The second clipping (Feb. 4, 1975) notes that the Smithsonian borrowed a Cashin for Philip Sills fur-lined leather coat and matching layered pants from 1957 for the exhibition.

Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (Newsday, Sept. 23, 1974) shows a photograph of Cashin's layered look of 1958.  It is potentially a photograph of Cashin's outfit on display in the Smithsonian exhibition "Suiting Everyone."  The second clipping ("Smithsonian") is a photograph of Cashin in a maxiskirt and a hat.

Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is a design forecast for 1975-1976.  Bonnie Cashin is quoted alongside Bill Blass, Halston, and Viola Sylbert.  She discusses her fur line.  The second item is a photograph of a woman in a canary yellow sweater dress with a matching cardigan.  This same picture is also in the third clipping (The Sacramento Union, March 27, 1975).

Title: Page 28a
AltTitle.other: A covey of Cashins!|~|Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills trunk show|~|Cashin fashions spell Fall "magic"
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is a brief advertisement for a Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills trunk show on August 1st and 2nd.  The second is an advertisement for (possibly the same?) a trunk show at the Carriage Shop Terrace of Cashin's Fall 1974 line for Philip Sills.  The third clipping (July 31, 1974) discusses the opening of the new Carriage Shop Terrace store and the Cashin event that will be its grand opening.  There is a photograph of a woman in a Cashin jacket, turtleneck sweater, pants, and hood.

Title: Page 29a
AltTitle.other: Showtime: Bonnie Cashin's Knittery
Description.note: One clipping, from St. Louis Globe-Democrat, August 11, 1975 (source and date handwritten in top right corner).  Advertisement for Bonnie Cashin's Knittery.  There are two drawings of women in Cashin's Knittery designs.  One woman wears a bronze/orange shetland wool "No" coat ($122), a tri-color tunnel-neck pullover, and sandalwood pants ($170).  The other woman wears a Shetland poncho ($86), a heather/bronze/gold tri-color pullover and pants ($84), and a tunnel-neck pullover ($57).

Title: Page 30b
AltTitle.other: Three more for the show|~|Designers size up coming TV special
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (L.A. Times, March 12, 1975) discusses the Coty Awards.  Bonnie Cashin for H.B.A. Corp. is cited as a winner for her fur designs.  The second (N.Y. Post, May 13, 1975) discusses the Pilgrim influence in Cashin's collection for Philip Sills.  The delicious vineyard colors of Cashin's native California are also discussed.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: coatdresses|~|bathrobes|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|stripes|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|trousers|~|blouses (main garments)|~|maxiskirts|~|shirts|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 31a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie tends to her knitting
Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten on top "N.Y. Post - Feb. 25/75."  Article discussing Bonnie Cashin's The Knittery.  There are four sketches accompanying the article.  The first is a bared little ankle length dress in white lamb's wool ($100) with finer ribbing for the top.  This woman also wears a large hat.  The second skethc is of a natural and white pure lamb's wool pants outfit with a striped Noh shirt (outfit: $155).  This woman wears a conical, Asian-inspired hat.  The third sketch is of a woman in a bubble top that is elasticized to wear pulled down over the hips in white pure wool with lean pants (outfit: $165).  She also wears a large hat and carries a shoulder bag.  The fourth woman wears a roomy, versatile Noh coat in brushed Shetland for $150.  This coat doubles as a bathrobe or coatdress.  She also wears a conical, Asian-inspired hat.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 31b
AltTitle.other: I. Magnin|~|Good looks for the great outdoors
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is black and white.  Below the photograph is handwritten "Harpers Bazaar 1974."  There is a photograph of a woman in a long quilted skirt in deep moss green, a leather-trimmed mohair jacket in gray, two mufflers sewn together, and a babuskha-tied scarf.  They are all by Bonnie Cashin for Phillip Sills.  The woman poses with a horse.  The second clipping is an advertisement for I. Magnin.  There is a color photograph of a woman's face and shoulders.  She wears fur around her shoulders, a hood, and sunglasses.  The locations of I. Magnin (California, Seattle, Portland, Phoenix, Chicago) above the photograph.

AltTitle.other: What makes you tick?  The uncompromising strength of American dressing by Bonnie Cashin.  Pioneer vigor to match your present-day spirit.
Description.note: One clipping.  From The New York Times, September 10, 1975.  Advertisement for Bonnie Cashin at Saks Fifth Avenue.  There is a photograph of two women.  One wears a mandarin-collared jacket in double-faced gray and camel wool ($225).  The other wears a double-faced, single-breasted coat in gray and camel wool, swathed in a scarf ($300).

AltTitle.other: Hot weather preview
Description.note: One clipping.  From the November 1975 issue of Vogue.  A photograph (from the Hot Weather Preview) of a woman in a nubbly-knit cardigan of natural cotton, linen, and silk by Bonnie Cashin's Knittery.  The woman also wears Jones cotton pants.

Title: Page 33b
AltTitle.other: On the 2nd day, bundle her|~|Bonnie Cashin and Collins & Aikman's Cavella|~|One of this year's great sweaters|~|Lower heat-- higher fashions
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin and COllins & Aikman's Cavella Arnel Fleece to be worn informally in the garden or at home.  The dress is long, with a belt tie, buttons down the front, and pink.  The second clipping has "Vogue" written below the clipping in pen.  There is a photograph of several funnle neck cashmere pullover sweaters ($115).  The third clipping has written in pen "Detroit Sund. News-" and there is a photograph of a woman in a golden brown velour sweatshirt ankle-length dress with a rib knit cowl collar and cuffs. Handwritten below is "Aug/75".  The fourth clipping has a photograph of a woman in a headcloth and a pink boudoir coat by Bonnie Cashin for Evelyn Pearson.  The coat is made of warm acrylic baby-bunting with acetate satin binding.  It comes in blue and pink.

AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin's versatile knit smock to wear with pants, skirts.|~|Bonnie Cashin for Meyers|~|Bonnie Cashin's patchwork leather
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin at Lord & Taylor.  There is a drawing of of a patchwork leather jacket in redwing ($180).  On top of the advertisement is handwritten "New Yorker /75."  The second clipping is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin for Meyers.  There is a sketch of a woman in a hat that ties under the chin, wearing a shirt, pants, and carrying a variety of bags and backpacks.  The third clipping is a color advertisement.  A woman is shown in a versatile knit smock ($55) in cotton and linen from Ireland.  The top of the shirt is hand loomed, and the rest hand crocheted.

Title: Page 34d
AltTitle.other: First choice gifts for 1975|~|Fashion focus on home sewing
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first shows an American Express card with a red ribbon around it surrounded by the text "First Choice Gifts for 1975."  The second shows a woman in a camel colored poncho with large pockets.  The third clipping discusses a softening and loosening of silhouettes for 1974.  There are three drawings of dresses: The BigTop shirtdress in brown and white cotton ticking; the unconstructed "Non-Suit" in printed crepe or sheer wool; and a soft fluid Sweaterdress in knit or crochet.  The sweaterdress is circled in black marker.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 35a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin's Knittery
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is a cover (?) of "Cue: The Weekly Entertainment Guide to the New York Area" for March 11-March 17, 1974.  There is a painting of a woman in a long gold maxidress and a red headscarf on the cover.  She also has a jacket that matches her dress slung over her shoulder.  It is unclear if it is a Cashin design or not.  The second clipping is reads "Action! ADG" on the top of the page.  It is from February 24, 1975.  This clipping is a business letter to "Designer Sporswear Buyers & Merchandies Managers" from Linda Melnick.  The letter describes Bonnie Cashin's Knittery's sportswear line.  Various items and prices are mentioned in the letter.

Title: Page 35b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin has a way with beige & cream...|~|Breeze into Spring
Description.note: Two clippings one from Cleveland Press January 28, 1975.  The other clipping is from January 1975 with an unknown source.  The first clipping has two images from Bonnie Cashin's Spring collection.  The one on the left features a coatdress (or "jersey" in the copy) which is red on one side and bamboo on the other.  It is half belted with a leather dog leash.The second image features an overcoat ("circular coat" in copy) in houndstooth.  It is worn over a hooded gray jersey.The second clipping is an advertisement with a sketch and description.  The sketch shows a beige and cream striped casual shirt over cream slacks.  The outfit costs $175.

Description.note: One clipping.  An advertisement for Bonnie Cashin's knits at The Clubhouse at Lobé.  There are drawings of many of Cashin's designs including: the perennial Noh coat in a flat-knit wool, a bubble coat, a funnel-neckline (turtleneck) pullover, a long and loose t-shirt dress, a gutsy big pullover, a brushed Shetland, poncho, and fluffy ankle-length Shetland coat. AltTitle.other: Knit-pickers who travel light
Description.note: One clipping, from Women's Wear Daily, March 6, 1975.  Article discussing Bonnie Cashin's Knittery designs.  Cashin discusses how great knits can be for travel.  There is a photograph of Cashin in a cardigan and trousers.  There is also a sketch of four women.  They wear: a red wool pullover jacket with funnel sweater and pants; a moss green shetland poncho with long knitted gloves, head wrap, and Cashin-carry bag; full-length Noh coat; and long chocolate and grape striped dress with long grape Shetland muffler.

Title: Page 39a
Description.note: One clipping, from Women's Wear Daily, March 6, 1975.  Article discussing the designs of Bonnie Cashin and Valerie Louthan.  There is a photograph of Valerie Louthan, as well as some sketches of her designs.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 39b
AltTitle.other: Pattern makers|~|See our collection of Bonnie Cashin knits|~|Cool cotton
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first (handwritten: "July 1975 Dallas Morning News") is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin knits at Sanger Harris.  There is a drawing of a woman in a wool turtleneck dress that comes in grety or beige and costs $110.  The second clipping (handwritten: "Women's Wear Daily, Wednesday, April 2, 1975") notes Cashin's use of stripes.  There is a drawing of a grape and peat wool mid-calf T-dress from Cashin's line for the Knittery.  The dress is topped with a big brown shetland poncho.  The third clipping (handwritten: "Long Island, March 30, 1975") shows a woman in a natural cotton and linen blend hand-crocheted lacy tube dress with a bateau neck.  Underneath she wears a Danskin flesh-color body stocking.  The fourth clipping is a photograph of a store wil clothing and handbags.  There is a large sign that reads "Bonnie Cashin."

Around the calendar are drawings of women in various designers' designs.  On the top left of the calendar, is a design from Bonnie Cashin's Knittery line.  The woman wears a hood, pants, a coat, and a shirt (possibly a pullover sweater?).

The calendar notes fashion shows at various stores.  Cashin's fur design is circled in red on the bottom left.  The woman in the sketch wears a fur jacket, pants, and a turtleneck sweater.

Subject: scarves (costume accessories)|~|ponchos|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|stripes|~|turtleneck sweaters--1970-1980|~|fur|~|plaids|~|maxiskirts|~|hats|~|headcloths (headgear)|~|slacks
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 41b
AltTitle.other: Newsy knits
Description.note: 5 clippings.  The first is from Women's Wear Daily, October 8, 1975.  This clipping has a drawing of a woman in a striped turtleneck with a hood.  She also wears either loose-fitting pants or a skirt (?).  The brief text discusses Cashin's latest Knittery collection and its use of Sea Island cotton yarn from Scotland.  The second clipping is from Folio: A Celebration of Independence from Saks Fifth Avenue, Autumn 1975 (cover pictured).  There is a photograph of a woman in a Cashin hat, 56-inch scarf, and a sweater of bronze-color wool ribbed horizontally across the yoke, vertically elsewhere.  The third clipping is from the Sunday Plain Dealer, September 14, 1975.  There is a photograph of two women, one in a bright orange mohair poncho ($86) and the other in a Noh coat in brushed taupe mohair ($176).  They also wear hats and headscarves and loose-fitting pants.  The fourth clipping shows a man in a suit and a woman in a long yellow Cashin cashmere sweater dress with a fluid cowl turtleneck.  She also wears a black mink coat.  The fifth clipping shows a woman in a white Cashin cowl-neck turtleneck over a basic trouser.  She also wears a white close-fitting hat or hood (?) and a black mink coat.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)

Title: Page 42a
AltTitle.other: She'll take the high road, he'll take the low road|~|Fashion talk: sportswear becomes the everything outfit
Description.note: One clipping.  First clipping is from (handwritten:) New York Times, October 8, 1975.  This article discusses a new surge in sportswear by various designers.  There are three photographs of designs by Calvin Klein and Bill Haire for Friedricks.  Cashin is discussed in the article and the paragraphs about her are outlined in a red box.  The second clipping has handwritten on the bottom: "NY Times November 13, 1975, Bonwitt Teller."  There is a drawing of a man and a woman in sweaters.  The woman wears a cowl that can shift to a hood from Bonnie Cashin's Knittery.  It comes in black, white, or red flame and costs $90.

Title: Page 42b
Description.note: 1 clipping.  From January 1976 Vogue.  There are three photographs.  The largest shows a woman in a Cashin "knitted everything jacket" in rust Shetland woll with ribbed band, tie belt. The second photograph shows a woman in a Cashin cashmere and jersey Chestnut turtleneck sweater with the neck pulled up into a hood.  She also wears a Shetland muffler and a mid-calf ginger wool jersey tube trimmed in tan leather.  The third photograph shows a woman in a loose-fitting cardigan, trousers, and boots.

Description.note: One clipping.  Advertisement for Avon Dew Kiss under makeup moisturizer and Avon lip dew chapstick.  The woman in the advertisement wears a red cowl neck/ hooded sweater by Bonnie Cashin.

Title: Page 44a
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is a clipping from The Observer Review, January 18, 1976.  There is an article discussing how to mix expensive and cheaper items.  One of the outfits used as an example features a long cardigan of Cashin's.  On the left hand side there is a note scrawled that wraps around the image: "Dear Bonnie - Here's another clip for your file - Hope all goes well for you - I've been a victim of the [illegible] + feel a bit low - [signature illegible]."  The second clipping is a photograph of a woman in a poncho in a choirboy style in cream and taupe.  Cashin's name is underlined in red and there is an arrow pointing up to the image.  Written on the image in red and underlined is "Me."

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|skirts (garments)|~|scarves (costume accessories)|~|ponchos|~|pullovers|~|hoods (headgear)|~|stripes|~|dresses (garments)|~|trousers|~|cowl neck collar|~|maxiskirts|~|shirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 44b
AltTitle.other: Knits: the Summer story|~|Bonnie Cashin heads for Hawaii|~|Knits that are forever
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first has handwritten on top "New York Post, March 4, 1976."  The article discusses Cashin's work with knits.  There is a sketch of two women.  They wear a striped pullover with funnel cowl-or-hood, shown over swimsuit, which may also top skirts or pants.  The other wears a linky tank dress, again striped.  The second clipping has handwritten in the bottom right corner "Knittery July 1976."  The second clipping discusses Cashin's Knittery.  The article discusses the classic and hip designs from the Knittery.  It also mentions a few other Cashin projects.  There is a drawing of a woman in a maxi-dress with a hood, wearing a poncho with stripes around the edges and the neckline.  The third clipping has handwritten on the top of the clipping in red "9/21/76." and in pen "BC" and on the right hand side "September 21, 1976" is circled in pen.  There are five drawings of Cashin's designs.  The outfits show: pull-on pants, a pull-on long skirt, a pull-on calf-length skirt, a wrap top, a funnel top, the bubble top and the poncho over all. Sketched in the clipping are some of the ways to put it all together: the beige bubble top and pants; the same pants and top with the white poncho; the poncho worn swung over one shoulder with the beige funnel top sweater; the funnel sweater and the long side-slit skirt; the wrap top and the shorter pull-on skirt.  There is a pink circle drawn in between all of the clippings.

Subject: suits (main garments)|~|shawls |~|jackets (garments)|~|pullovers|~|hoods (headgear)|~|tweed|~|turtleneck sweaters--1970-1980|~|skirts (garments)--1970-1980|~|leather|~|trousers|~|jump suits
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 49b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin's not one for fantasy|~|Cashin styles, neither shocking nor faddish, "come naturally"
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (Dallas Times Herald, September 30, 1976) discusses Cashin's design philosophy.  The article deals with her feelings on layering, colors, current fashion, anthropology, and timelessness.  There is also a photograph of Cashin in a stripped hood and oversized shawl posing with two models in her styles.  One model wears a plaid suit and a hood, and the other wears a skirt, jacket, and turtleneck sweater.  The second clipping (The Globe and Mail, September 24, 1976) discusses Cashin's refusal to design fantasy clothes.  She prefers to design realistic clothes for realistic women.  There are two photographs accompanying the article.  One shows a woman in a Cashin coat, pullover, and pants.  The other shows a woman in a jumpsuit.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin, in person!
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Dallas Morning News, September 28, 1976.  The clipping is an advertisement to see Bonnie Cashin in person at the Neiman-Marcus in Dallas, Texas.  The text describes some of Cashin's achievements.  There are sketchs of women in Cashin coats, skirts, and turtleneck sweaters.  There is also a close-up sketch of an open travel-desk handbag.

AltTitle.other: Quality is...
Description.note: One clipping.  From Women's Wear Daily, February 27,1975.  A clipping giving examples of people and things that Women's Wear Daily describes as "quality."  A group of people are labeled at the top of the page as "quality people."  Below, there are a variety of quality things, such as a "postal system" or "fabrics."  Cashin is on the "fashion" list.  At the bottom of the page is handwritten "Hollow words dept."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 1c
AltTitle.other: Design genius Cashin' in|~|Designer speaks
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is The Dallas Morning News, October 1, 1976.  There is a handwritten note by the photograph in the article.  There is an "x" and says "this was sent to you from Sills -- should be worn with white headwrap --".  The article says that Cashin was in Dallas to present her Fall '76 collection at Neiman-Marcus.  Cashin discusses how the "public is back to being quality-minded."  It is also noted that many of her designs are seen in Europe as well as America.  Cashin's biography is also briefly discussed (her time as a costume designer in Los Angeles, etc), as well as her line for The Knittery.  The accompanying photograph shows Cashin, in a turtleneck sweater, poncho, pants, and headwrap, with two models.  One model wears: a cashmere, leather, and plaid wool pants ensemble of a poncho, pullover, sweater, and pants.  The other model wears a long white cashmere dress with bias cut Scotch plaid poncho type cape.  There is also a bag on the ground.  The second clipping is from the SUN, October 17, 1976.  The article notes that as a guest of the Minneapolis-St. Paul Fashion group, Cashin will speak to design students of the University in the auditorium of McNeal Hall, St. Paul Campus, October 22.  The article talks about some details of that event.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: turtleneck sweaters|~|collars (neckwear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|fur|~|plaids|~|headcloths (headgear)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 2a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin fashion party
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from Skyway News, October 19, 1976.  This photograph shows a group of women modeling Bonnie Cashin coats.  They all wear coats, some with fur accents.  The women pictured are Helen Connery, general manager of Harold's; Ruth Shipley, Star & Tribune, producer of Mall Fashion Show; Pam Quinlan, Daytons; Ginger Shaw, design coordinator of Wonderalls; Margot Siegel, SHE public relations; and Gloria Hogan SHE publications.  The second clipping (possibly from the same source?) show photographs of a variety of guests at the opening of the Twin Cities Fashion Group Collection (costumes from 1930 - 1960).  The Fashion Group presented a retrospective of Miss Cashin's clothes from the 1940s to the 1967-77 fall and winter fashions, with movies and slides of her creations.  There are photographs of a multitude of guests, along with a photograph of Cashin in a headwrap and an elaborate neck ruffle.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|skirts (garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|leather|~|suede
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 2b
AltTitle.other: Fashion group assembles women's clothing for use by students, posterity
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Minneapolis Tribune, October 17, 1976.  Article discussing the efforts of the Minneapolis-St. Paul Fashion Group to collect garments from the 1930s through the present (1976) to be housed at the new Goldstein Gallery in the McNeal Hall on the St. Paul campus of the University of Minnesota.  There are two photographs of three Cashin outfits.  The photographs have to red "x"'s next to them.  One photograph shows a hooded Pied Piper jacket.  The other shows an ivory leather suit, and a salmon suede skirt and smock top.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|evening dresses (garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|ponchos|~|capes (outerwear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|mohair|~|sweater sets--1970-1980|~|trousers|~|suede|~|plaids|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 3a
AltTitle.other: New Home Ec complex opens|~|Owners keeping Cashin designs|~|Bonnie Cashin to attend gala
Description.note: One clipping, in color.  The clipping is from the St. Paul Sunday Pioneer Press, October 17, 1976.  The article deals with the opening of a new building and renovated space of the College of Home Economics McNeal Hall complex at the University of Minnesota's St. Paul campus.  Bonnie Cashin was a guest at the gala celebration.  A variety of Cashin's designs are pictured in the complex.  Cashin's designs from various seaons (12 years prior, 5 years prior, etc) are shown as examples of the timelessness of Cashin's designs.  The designs pictured are: a plaid cape coat; a cape over a bloomer dress; a Noh jacket and pants in suede with a hooded sweater; a mohair plaid hooded coat; a suede trimmed plaid poncho and coordinating pants; and a historical orchid satin formal dress with a matching jacket.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 3b
AltTitle.other: University: Bonnie Cashin to show collection|~|Fashion: hotpants, topless swimsuit fads represented in group collection
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from St. Paul Sunday Pioneer Press, October 17, 1976.  This clipping is the second part of an article.  The first part of the article is not included in this clipping.  This article discusses Cashin's biography.  It also discusses that she has very little to do with the selling of her designs.  It also talks about Cashin's appearance at the McNeal Hall auditorium, the renovation of the McNeal building, and the multimedia fashion retrospective.  The second clipping is also the second part of an article, though the first part of the article is not attached to this clipping.  This article discusses the University of Minnesota's collection of garments dating from the 1830's to 1930.  The article talks about details of the gallery and the collection, such as its hours.  Its noted that one of the fads represented in the collection is hotpants.  Additionally some specific donations of pieces are noted.

Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is an advertisement for Cardin de Pierre Cardin perfume at Bloomingdales.  It is from The New York Times Magazine, October 17, 1976.  There is a photograph of a woman in a (Cashin?) cowl neck sweater that has been pulled into a hood.  The second clipping is from Women's Wear Daily, October 30, 1976.  There is a photograph of a woman in a fawn colored suede overblouse that snaps down the back and glen plaid wool bloomers called Amelias, after Amelia Bloomer.

Title: Page 4b
AltTitle.other: SA spring collections: fresh and wearable
Description.note: One clipping.  From Women's Wear Daily, November 5, 1976.  This article is the second part of an article, but the first part of the article is not included with this clipping.  The sections discussing Cashin and her designs are bracketed in red.  Cashin's name is also underlined in red.  Cashin is discussed in the article in terms of her Spring collection for Sills & Co.  There is a sketch of Cashin's accompanying the article that shows a tan buck suede sleeveless tunic trimmed in white leather, a white jersey shirt, and white leather shorts with zip pockets.

AltTitle.other: Short subjects are not main feature in this week's Spring fashion shows
Description.note: One clipping, from the Daily News, November 5, 1976.  Article discussing hemlines at the Spring fashion show.  Designs by a variety of designers are featured.  The section discussing Cashin is bracketed in red.  The photograph of her design is also boxed in red.  The woman in the photograph wears a long almost knee-length vest, a shirt, and shorts.  She also wears a headcloth.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 5b
AltTitle.other: Joyful fashions with a folkloric flavor
Description.note: One clipping.  From The New York Times, November 6, 1976.  Article discussing the folkloric and peasant influences on fashion.  Bonnie Cashin's canvas bloomers are discussed.  There is a photograph of a woman in a turtleneck sweater, a jacket, and the bloomers.  The article discusses how Cashin's appeal is more suburban than tropical and how her strength is in country clothes that work with functional details.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 6a
AltTitle.other: Superlative|~|After pants, bloomers are kicky fashion
Description.note: Clipping 2: advertisement for Cashin at I. Magnin.  A lambswool cream and taupe stripe Noh sweater with finders keepers hidden pockets is shown.  Also creamy sweater knit pants are shown.|~|Clipping 1, New York Times, 11/9/1976: "After Pants, Bloomers Are Kicky Fashion / By Bernadine Morris" This article discusses the rise in popularity of bloomers.  A variety of designers are discussed and accompanying images of those designers' designs are featured.  Discussed and featured are: Yves Saint Laurent, Bonnie Cashin, Rosita Missoni, and Giorgio Sant'Angelo.  Cashin is noted as calling bloomers "Amelias" after Amelia Bloomer, the suffragette who wore them.  Cashin's checkered wool city suit is shown, along with a headwrap and a tube top.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 6b
AltTitle.other: 100% Lamb's wool pantsuits the Bonnie Cashin way|~|Styles with a lift
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from the New York Post, November 16, 1976.  The article discusses Cashin's joyous, playful use of color and shape, for example her tabards, ponchos, and other new, fun shapes.  There are three photographs.  They show: plaid bloomers, and a flannel blazer bound in leather; flannel shorts with zipped pockets under a sleeveless suede jacket (vest?); and a leather side-tied tabard with a leather pleated skirt.  The second clipping is an advertisement for Cashin's lamb's wool pantsuits at Mac Hugh, Inc. There are two drawings of women in the pantsuits.  They come in an array of colors and the two shown costs $156 and $143 respectively.  The women in the drawings also wear sweaters.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 7
AltTitle.other: 'Antique' clothes have been enjoying a popular renaissance
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Chicago Tribune, December 27, 1976.  There is an article discussing the recent trend of "antique" clothes, thanks to Barbra Streisand.  The article tries to ascertain what will be seen as the 70s "antiques" in the 21st century.  A number of designers are mentioned.  There is a red bracket in pen around Cashin's secion which mentions that "almost any" design by Cashin will be considered an important 70s antique.

Description.note: One clipping.  From The Courier-Journal, March 14, 1977.  This clipping has photographs of 14 designs by 14 different designers.  There is a section that can be cut out in this clipping that enables one to vote for the Louisville look and pick one of the designs.  The designers shown are: Anne Klein, Bill Blass, Jerry Silverman, Albert Nipon, Ralph Lauren, Kasper, Halston, Mollie Parnis, Diane Von Furstenburg, Pauline Trigere, Bonnie Cashin, Calvin Klein, Bill Kaiserman, and Liz Claiborne.

Title: Page 6b
AltTitle.other: Fall knitwear|~|Energy-sparing clothes
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from Women's Wear Daily, April 6, 1977.  This clipping has a small sketch of a "little-coat" from Bonnie Cashin's Knittery.  The coat is made from a thick, crunchy wool and mohair yarn.  It also has big rolled cuffs with winter-white intarsia design among a tweedy mix of brown and brass tones.  There is also a suede tie.  The woman in the drawing also wears a hood and pants. There is a caption beneath the picture describing it.The second clipping is from Women's Wear Daily, May 10, 1977.  It discusses fashion and energy conservation.  Several designers are discussed.  Cashin's love of layers is discussed.  Some of her sketches are also featured.  There are three women in her sketches wearing a jacket, a skirt (dress?), a tube dress, a coat, a hood, and pants.

Title: Page 8b
AltTitle.other: Functional Fall fashions|~|Taking Noh-te|~|Winter's furs: magnificient, and very expensive
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first (The New York Times, June 4, 1977) discusses various designers' fur collections.  Cashin is mentioned, noting that her basic shapes are so good, she rarely changes them.  The second clipping (Women's Wear Daily, June 9, 1977) has a photograph of a fur Noh jacket from Cashin's fur collection for Rein, Rame & Gurvitch in natural feathered raccoon.  The third clipping (The Courier-Journal, June 2, 1977) features three photographs of Cashin designs.  Shown in the photographs: cashmere tights, boots, sweater, fur parka, plaid suit (bubble top and narrow trousers).  The article discusses the functionality of Cashin's collection.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: ponchos|~|hoods (headgear)|~|plaids
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 9a
AltTitle.other: RAM reports to retailers
Description.note: One clipping.  From RAM Reports to Retailers, July 7, 1977.  There are several articles in the clipping and one accompanying (but physically separated) photograph.  Two of the three articles in the clipping mention Cashin.  One, "Speaking of Roots: The Kirkland Assignment #2" mentions Cashin in passing, in terms of a building she once worked in.  The other article focuses on Cashin.  The article discusses Cashin's fashion roots and her designs.  There is a photograph of Cashin in her studio.  The other photograph shows one of Cashin's tweed ponchos.  The model also wears a hood.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 9b
AltTitle.other: Feathery fabrics
Description.note: Four clippings.  Two are labeled Empire (or Empire Magazine) from August 28, 1977.  "Denver Post" is also written below Empire on one of those clippings.  The other two are not labeled, but feature the same model as the other two clippings.  The first clipping features a color photograph of a Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills candy-pink hooded poplin storm coat with dyed-to-match plush lining.  The model also wears black boots with a chunky heel.  The second clipping features a black and white photograph of a Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills sand and taupe shadow plaid wool shirtdress.  The third clipping shows another color photograph of a candy-pink coat.  This one, though, is a hooded mohair coat paired with a wool jersey dress.  They are also Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills.  This model wears black boots as well.  The fourth clipping is a black and white photograph of a corduroy bubble blouson with a matching skirt (both also Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills).

Title: Page 11b
AltTitle.other: Cashin's fashions: where she leads the rest follow
Description.note: Two clippings.  One appears to be the first page of the other.  The second page is labeled with The Washington Star, September 29, 1977.  The clippings feature a Q&A interview with Bonnie Cashin.  She discusses her original designs, Parsons student designs, and her definition of fashion among other things.  On the first clipping there is also a photograph of Cashin.  In the second clipping there are four photographs featuring Cashin designs: zoave pants, a poncho/shawl, a jacket with slashes in the back, and a fringed upper garment.

There is a photograph of four women modeling Cashin designs.  Their outfits include: a beret, a long leather coat with fur, a coat with a hood, a matching corduroy skirt suit, hoods, a jacket, and a turtleneck sweater.

Name.subject: Harper's Bazaar (magazine)
Title: Page 13a
AltTitle.other: Cashin's fashions weather history|~|The great coat by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first ("9/7/79" is written in pencil) is a fun look backstage at a Bonnie Cashin fashion show.  There are quotations from the designer as she puts finishing touches on her designs before the show and prepares the models.  For example, Cashin tries to decide which design would best go with the sable collie that will be in the show, and attempts to find a Dalmatian.  There are two photographs of Cashin with some models in her designs.  Cashin wears a sweater and skirt.  The models pictured wear jackets, coats, sweaters, and hoods.  The second clipping (Sept. 1977) is an advertisement for a Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills greatcoat which costs $420.  The model in the advertisement also wears a 2-piece wool jersey dress, $280.  This clipping may be from Harper's Bazaar, as a Harper's Bazaar title from September is the third clipping.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 14b
AltTitle.other: Travel light in a layered look|~|"Goat to Coat" is a long story told in a word-- cashmere
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from the Los Angeles Times, October 30, 1977.  It is an article by Horace Sutton from a column entitled "A Traveler's Diary."  The article discusses the value of dressing in layers, as Cashin promotes, particularly in terms of traveling.  There is an accompanying sketch with three women depicting various stages of a layered outfit.  The outfit includes pants, a turtleneck sweater, a tunic (vest?), a coat, and a hood.  The second article is from The New Haven Register, November 3, 1977.  This article, by Marion McDonald (Family Editor), discusses cashmere.  There is a photograph of a woman in a cashmere evening dress by Cashin.

Title: Page 15a
AltTitle.other: 'Festival' winds up at Academy|~|It's Bonnie Cashin, who rhymes with fashion|~|Academy winds up 'Festival of Fibers'
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first two are part of the same article, possibly from the Waikiki Beach Press (there is also a clipping of the masthead).  This brief article discusses Cashin's lectures at the Honolulu Academy of Arts, as well as her designs.  Her lectures are entitled "Designs on My Mind" and "Making an Imprint on Modern Fashion."  The lectures are part of the Academy's "A Festival of Fibers" exhbition.  The third clipping from the Star-Bulletin, November 9, 1977.  The article discusses Cashin's designs and design philosophy.  There is a photograph of Cashin in a striped maxidress.

The three designers answer questions about contemporary fashion.  There is also a photograph of Cashin in a shawl, sweater, and trousers, holding a large zebra-print bag.

Description.note: One clipping.  Invitation for Bonnie Cashin and the Fashion Group of Portland at The Portland Art Museum.  There is a photograph of Cashin in a turtleneck and a necklace.  The invitation announces the Annual Fashion Benefit on November 3, 1977.  There will be two shows-- one at 7:00pm and one at 9:00pm, with complimentary champagne and a no host bar.  The event costs $12 per person

Title: Page 17a
AltTitle.other: Cashin mulls direction, seeks to expand image|~|Fashion it's a trip
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from The Oregonian, November 5, 1977.  This article has a photograph of Bonnie Cashin chatting with Fashion Group member Marla Hervin.  Cashin wears red cashmere (turtleneck sweater, pants?) with a red poncho.  She also holds a bag and wears a headwrap of some sort.  The article discusses Cashin's attendance at Fashion Group's gala as an honored guest.  Cashin's interest in education is dicssed, as well as her love for cashmere.  The second clipping (source and date unknown) has a photograph of a woman in a large light-colored poncho, with a scarf, beret, turtleneck, and trousers of similar color.  The accompanying article discusses a fashion spectacular at The Portland Art Museum when 13 Portland stores will present fashions for men and women, sponsored by Fashion Group, Inc.  The theme of the event is "Fashion is a Trip."  Cashin and her career are discussed as she is a special guest who will be commentating.

One shows a woman in a large light-colored mohair cape, with a scarf, beret, turtleneck, and trousers of similar color.  The other shows a red hooded canvas coat and dress.  The accompanying article discusses a fashion spectacular at The Portland Art Museum when 13 Portland stores will present fashions for men and women, sponsored by Fashion Group, Inc. The entire picture from the article is shown in the clipping 21198/zz0008bgt9

Title: Page 17c
AltTitle.other: Suede patch coat by Bonnie Cashin|~|Channel 13 umbrella|~|It's a fact...|~|Shooting-stick umbrella|~|"Expressly yours" gifts from American Express
Description.note: Six clippings.  Source and date unknown for most clippings.  The first clipping shows a picture of an American Express card on a train and reads "'Expressly Yours' gifts from American Express."  The second clipping appears to be cut from a catalog.  There is a photograph of a woman in a Cashin brushed shetland all wool poncho in heathery beige tones.  It has buttons down the front and costs $80.  There is pink marker underlining the price and the name of the poncho.  The third clipping looks as though it is from the the same catalog as the second clipping.  There is a picutre of a woman in a jacket made of multi-colored suede and smooth leather squares in warm tones.  No two coats are alike.  There are also twist-close brass buttons, acetate lining, and slit pockets in side seams.  It costs about $160.  Cashin's name and the price are underlined in pink.  The fourth clipping has handwritten on the top of the clipping "Nov. /77 McCalls".  Cashin's name is also underlined.  There is a drawing of an umbrella with handles that fold out to an uncomfortable but convenient seat.  It costs $40.  The fifth clipping is an advertisement [?] to become a member of WNET Thirteen.  The sixth clipping shows one of the membership incentives for WNET 13: an umbrella designed by Cashin in tan water-repellent nylon.  There are two arrows pointing at the caption.
