The second clipping is a cut-out from a catalog (?) of a shetland wool beige poncho.  It costs $80.  The third clipping has a picture of a multi-colored suede and smooth leather patchwork coat by Cashin.  It costs $160.  The fourth clipping shows a bunch of items one can get with a membership to THIRTEEN.  Cashin's THIRTEEN umbrella is shown.  The retail value is $22.

Title: Page 19a
AltTitle.other: Designers, all artists at heart...
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first clipping is the first part of an article continued in the second clipping.  The article is from The Boston Herald American, November 9, 1977.  There is a photograph of a woman in a jersey crop top traced with suede by Bonnie Cashin.  She also wears a hat and a four-cornered skirt carved of buttery suede.  The accompanying article argues that fashion is as much a part of the art world as it is the business world. A variety of artists and designers are mentioned as well as quoted.  The second clipping, the continuation of the article from the first clipping, discusses in what museum department clothes and costumes end up in, as well as some museum exhibitions of costumes.  There are also some more quotations by Cashin and other designers about artistic influences.  The third clipping has handwritten in the bottom right corner "Saks '77 Xmas".  This clipping is an advertisement for a Cashin tote with a jack pattern ($25), and two umbrellas with jack patterns ($20 and $25).

AltTitle.other: Fabulous fantasies with|~|Sakowitz Christmas '77|~|Bonnie Cashin's|~|The bubble by Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first is from The Germantown News, December 15, 1977.  There is a photograph of a woman in a Cashin feathered raccoon smock coat that offers voluminous, enveloping comfort.  The woman also wears a hat or a hood.  The second clipping is an advertisement for a elegant ranch mink bubble coat by Cashin.  The woman in the advertisement also wears a turtleneck sweater and has an umbrella.  The third clipping is in color and shows Cashin's big bundle-y blouson of dyed Golden Feather raccoon.  The jacket is hip-hugging and hooded and costs $2000.  The fourth clipping reads "Sakowitz Christmas '77 Peace."

The second clipping is from Fur Age Weekly, New York, NY, June 26, 1978.  There is a photograph of a fox bubble with a checkerboard effect of two different fox furs (Raisin and Earth Fox). Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 22a
AltTitle.other: Words that lawyers live by|~|Why can't lawyers talk like us?|~|A lesson in legal writing
Description.note: Two clippings.  From The Washington Post Outlook, January 15, 1978.  The first clipping is the first part of the article continued in the second clipping.  This section of the article notes that Bonnie Cashin refuses to sign any contracts containing "legal mumbo-jumbo, especially the word 'whereas.'"  Cashin's sense of taste is offended by wordy, incomprehensible legal language.  The article notes that Cashin is in the vanguard of a small but growing national movement as consumers and institutions across the country rebelling against the language of law.  The article continues discussing the confusing nature of legal language.  Cashin is mentioned again at the end of the article saying that she really wants to understand contracts.  The other articles in the clipping show how legal writing could be made clearer and pick out a few particularly confusing words.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: turtleneck sweaters|~|umbrellas
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 22b
AltTitle.other: Chicago style|~|The Cashin corps
Description.note: Two clippings.  One is a cover of the Chicago Sun-Times Chicago Style section, January 15, 1978.  The woman in this photograph wears a shirt, pants, and hat by several designers.  She also is pictured with a walking stick handled sun umbrella by Bonnie Cashin.  The second clipping is from The Trade, January-February 1978.  This article discusses Cashin's Cashin Corps of knitting senior citizens.  Cashin asks the legions of older women in the country who love to knit to translate some of her own ideas.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: vests (garments)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|fur|~|greatcoats|~|alpaca (fiber)|~|blazers
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 23a
AltTitle.other: Two top designers offer the cops an arresting new look
Description.note: One clipping.  This clipping is from the New York Post, February 24, 1978.  This article discusses Police Commissioner Rober J. McGuire's decision that the police force's current winter uniforms are no longer acceptable.  The New York Post asked designers how they would solve the problem of the uniforms.  Halston's drawings are featured, along with Cashin's.  Two of Cashin's designs are shown.  The first shows a blazer cut work jacket - available with or without a collar - with a soft shoulder cotton turtleneck shirt and a bullet proof knit vest.  The other drawing shows a top coat made of waterproof tough canvas and with a removable alpaca lining.  The coat includes: a badge of honor, raglan sleeve for creature comfort, new tornlock closure with insignia, easy access pocket, slit in side seam for access to pants pocket, inside zip pockets on each side, and a detachable parka hood for deep freeze.

Description.note: Four clippings.  The first clipping is from Women's Wear Daily, February 23, 1978.  This article features three drawings of cashmere outfits.  These sketchs show striped sweaters, vests, ribbed bodysuits, pants, and skirts.  The second clipping shows a plunging, drawstring bubble in natural cashmere over striped funnel-neck sweater and natural pull-on; the rib-trimmed, tiered twins -- a gray cashmere hooded cardigan over a longer matching pull and a sliver-of-a-skirt.  The third clipping has handwritten below "4/24/78".  There is a photograph of a big quilted yellow nylon bubble jacket and a turquoise canvas jacket worn over a purple sleeveless coat.  The fourth clipping discusses Bonnie Cashin Weatherwear for Russ Taylor collection.  Cashin's signature shape -- big and roomy -- is discussed.

AltTitle.other: The sweater dressing|~|Bonnie Cashin designs in Borg's animal like pile fabrics
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from Women's Wear Daily, April 15, 1978.  This clipping shows drawings of designs by Betty Hanson, Bonnie Cashin, and Carol Horn.  Cashin's designs shown are a handknitted, tawny mohair hooded blouson with lean, pull-on breeches in fine lambswool.  The second clipping is an advertisement for Cashin at the Borg Textile Corporation.  The text reads "Bonnie Cashin designs in Borg's animal like pile fabrics -- so warm and weightless they'll make Bonnie Cashin people love Bonnie more."

Title: Page 24b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin's designs treated with Zepel|~|Bonnie Cashin designs in Glenoit's fabulous furry look fabrics made with Verel
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin designs in Glenoit.  The text reads " Bonnie Cashin designs in Glenoit's fabulous furry look fabrics made with Verel... for inside fashion that will make Bonnie Cashin people love Bonnie more."  The second clipping is an advertisement for Cashin clothes made with Du Pont Ze Pel.  The text reads "Bonnie Cashin's designs treated with Ze Pel makes everyday sunny and will make Bonnie Cashin people love Bonnie more."

Title: Page 25a
AltTitle.other: We're getting our feet wet!|~|Bonnie Cashin designs in Earl-Glo fabrics- that make fashion, will make Bonnie Cashin people love Bonnie more
Description.note: Two clippings.  The firs has a light drawing of a figure from around the shoulders and above.  The figure wears a hat, a scarf, and either a coat or a cape.  The text superimposed on the figure reads "Bonnie Cashin designs in Earl-Glo fabrics- that make fashion, will make Bonnie Cashin people love Bonnie more."  The second clipping features the full body image of the figure from the first clipping.  The figure wears a hat, a scarf, a coat or a cape, and holds an umbrella.  The superimposed text reads "We're getting our feet wet!  Russel Taylor announces with pride a new enterprise -Bonnie Cashin weatherwear for Russ Taylor.  For wet day people, for cold day people, and for people who love Bonnie Cashin."

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 25b
AltTitle.other: The accent is on comfort|~|Fashion notes
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from The Washington Post, May 21, 1978.  This clipping has a series of short notes on various fashion related items.  The second section deals with Cashin's Weatherwear for Russ Taylor.  Her contemporary shapes are mentioned, as well as an impromptu retro show of Cashin's clothes at her Smithsonian lecture which sruprised Cashin.  A sketch of one of Cashisn's designs is featured alongside the article: a waterproof poplin bubble jacket and skinny pants.  The second clipping is from the New York Post, June 6, 1978.  This article has two accompanying photographs: one shows a quilted poplin coat with a hood worn over matching knickers and cowl neck sweater, and the other photograph shows a snuggley, bulky, hand knit sweater from Cashin's Knittery worn over pants.  The article discusses the value Cashin places on comfort, as well as Cashin's thoughtful designs.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|skirts (garments)|~|scarves (costume accessories)|~|purses (ladies' accessories)|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|tube tops|~|shirts|~|hats|~|headcloths (headgear)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 26a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: One clipping.  Magazine [?] title above the clipping reads "May / June Ambiance".  The clipping has a bit of information about Cashin, noting that she is a third-generation Californian and a modern architect of clothes.  There are four sketches of Cashin's outfits with brief colorful descriptions of each outfit by Cashin.  The first sketch shows a natural cotton and linen cap sleeved bubble top that is partly kint and partly crochet.  The woman also wears a headcloth and a skirt made of Indonesian cotton with a tiny tie-dyed pattern.  The second sketch shows a piece of African cotton wrapped into a tube top.  The woman also wears a skirt and a canvas tote based on Cashin's own zebra rug.  The third sketch shows an outfit made of silks from Thailand and India.  The silks have a big floral print with bands on the sleeves.  The fourth sketch shows a knitted and boucled sweater.  She also wears a hat and trousers.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: purses (ladies' accessories)|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|leather|~|shoulder bags
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 26b
AltTitle.other: The new suppleness in leather will surprise you, unless you know Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: One clipping.  From The New York Times, June 25, 1978.  Advertisement for Cashin bags at Meyers.  The bags included are: a feed bag with a small sac inside (10" x 4" x 10", $74); an ample hobo on a rectangular base with a zippered top that folds over softly with a small sac inside (12" x 5 1/2" x 11", $76); a soft tote with drawstring and small sac inside (13" x 4 1/2" x 12", $79); and a hunting bag with drawstring in front under flap, with a zippered pocket inside (9" x 3 1/2" x 9 1/2", $73).

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|scarves (costume accessories)|~|ponchos|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|trousers|~|umbrellas|~|greatcoats|~|knickerbockers|~|raincoats|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 27a_a
AltTitle.other: Coats feature broad shoulder lines|~|Thinking ahead
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first clippings is from Quincy, Mass. Patriot Ledger, July 13, 1978.  This article deals with how designers usually do not design clothes for the rigors of northern winters.  However, as the article notes, Bonnie Cashin does.  The article continues describing her stylish yet toasty and thus practical items.  There are several accompanying pictures.  They show: a nylon quilted coat with matching quilted bloomers; a bright red poplin poncho with a hood and lined with simulated raccoon; a poplin coat with a zingy red flannel lining and fringed scarf; and a rainsuit with a waterproof jacket and pants.  The second clipping also has a picture of the rainsuit, with the caption underlined in red.  This article discusses the broad shoulders of designers' coats.  The section on Cashin is bracketed in red.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: cat suits|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|trousers
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 27a_b
AltTitle.other: The Knittery|~|Versatility: sweater story|~|Advertisers
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first is from KnitOvations '78.  This clipping is an advertisement from The Knittery.  There is a sketch of a woman in a knitted body suit that covers everything but the woman's eyes.  The second clipping is a list of advertisers from an unknown source.  Cashin's name is listed.  The third clipping (possibly from the same source as the list of advertisers?) has photographs of a variety of designers' outfits.  Cashin's hand-knit intarsia striped bubble, layered over a funnel pullover and lambswool knitted pants.  The fourth clipping is from the Charleston, West Virginia Gazette, July 31, 1978.  This article talks about sweaters from Cashin's collections.  The price ranges for her hand-knit items from $210 to $340.  Her pricey cashmeres are also discussed but Cashin says "like a Charles Eames chair, they won't go out of fashion."

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 27b
AltTitle.other: Cashin's clothes: three decades of comfort
Description.note: One clipping.  From The New York Times, July 3, 1978.  Article discussing Cashin as an American fashion institution.  Her coats are noted as a strong point of her collections, and her practicality praised.  There are four accompanying sketches.  They show: a deep freeze coat (canvas, lined with fake fox fur), a hand-knitted sweater-jacket, a hand-knitted intarsia design sweater, and a quilted nylons torm coat with matching pants.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|ponchos|~|cashmere (wool)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|sweaters--1970-1980|~|stripes|~|leggings|~|fur|~|greatcoats|~|robes (main garments)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 28a
AltTitle.other: A Bonnie winter|~|Playing hostess
Description.note: Three clippings.  The firstis from Living Today, King Features Syndicate, July 28, 1978.  This clipping features an article by Bonnie Cashin about being a hostess and entertaining.  Cashin discusses her relationship with parties ("I don't give them-- they happen to me") as well as her secrets for giving parties ("...I'm generally up at the crack of dawn.").  She also notes her cooking tips for parties.  There is a photograph of Cashin in a striped robe (?) and a hat (or headwrap?).  The second clipping is from the Livonia, Michigan Tro Eccentric, August 31, 1978.  The text under the photograph is underlined in red.  There is a photograph of a woman in an easy tie front greatcoat lined in simulated fox is Bonnie Cashin's way of dressing for open air sports events.  The deep freeze snuggery coat is her first Weatherwear Collection for Russ Taylor.  The third clipping is from 1977 and shows three sketches of Cashin's designs.  The Knittery designs shown include a cashmere bubble top over a funnel-neck sweater and tights (leggings?), as well as a supple dress, thong-wrapped at the waist, and a poncho.  For Rein, Rame, and Gurvitch there is a coyote casual coat shown.  There is also a brief article about Cashin's cashmere creations.

Title: Page 28b
AltTitle.other: Halle's introduces the first Bonnie Cashin Weatherwear for Russ Taylor
Description.note: One clipping, handwritten on the bottom of the page is "The Cleveland Plain Dealer, Aug. 15, 1978".  The clipping is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin Weatherwear for Russ Taylor at Halle's.  There is a drawing of two weathercoats and accessories.  The weathercoats are turf with plaid lining ($170), and natural with red lining or black with camel-color lining (also $170).  The women are also pictured with a scarf, a hat, and an umbrella.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|scarves (costume accessories)|~|jackets (garments)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|raincoats--1970-1980|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|trousers|~|umbrellas|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 29a
AltTitle.other: A new snow queen?  Cashin hot on cold|~|Gala events request utterly feminine look|~|About weatherwear... a Bonnie Cashin philosophy
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from Cameo, August 14, 1978.  The article discusses the special way one must dress in order to meet rain head on.  There are various types of rain and thus various types of clothes fit to deal with rain.  There is a photograph of Cashin's raincoat with zingy red flannel lining, and a long fringed scarf.  The raincoat is made of a Zepel finished cotton duck poplin.  The woman also wears a hat and carries an umbrella.  Cashin's name is underlined in red as well as the phrase "(continued on page 17)".  The second clipping is from The Trade, August 1978.  This article discusses Cashin's great strength in realm of outerwear.  Many of Cashin's Weatherwear for Russel Taylor are described.  Two sketches of Cashins' Weatherwear accompany the article.  They show: a seasonless poplin as a bubble to wear with skirts, skinny shorts, or pants; and a silk-touch Qiana molded into a generously cut all-weather coat with sleeves that "grow right out of the body."  The women in the sketches also have umbrellas.  The third clipping is from the Livonia, Mich. Birmingham Eccentric, August 31, 1978.  This article discusses Pat Rosseau who outfits customers at the fashion department of Walton Pierce in Troy.  Cashin's canvas and simulated fox coat is described as being perfect for an afternoon of football on the first really chill fall day.  The two sections discussing Cashin's coat are bracketed in red.

Description.note: One clipping.  Source and date unknown.  Advertisement for clothes that exemplify the best of country living in American fashion.  There is a photograph of a woman with a horse.  The woman wears clothes from a variety of designers, including a funnel-neck cashmere pullover by Bonnie Cashin.

AltTitle.other: Rugged clothes, comfortable ramblin' clothes for country walks, city strides
Description.note: Two clippings.  One is the article and caption discussing the photograph.  There is also the cover title for the source (?) of the clippings: L'Officiel USA: The Magazine of International Fashion.  The issue is from September but the year is unknown.  The photograph shows a Bonnie Cashin for Russ Taylor all weather jacket of beige canvas with a pile lining ($130), lambswool bloomers ($100), and a beige handknit mohair hooded bubble sweater ($240).

Title: Page 30b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin Weatherwear for Russ Taylor|~|Tomorrow, come see our new collection of Bonnie Cashin storm coats at our exclusive showing.|~|Bonnie Cashin country classic
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from the Register-Guard, Eugene, Oregon, September 3, 1978.  This is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin Weatherwear for Russ Taylor at Town + Travel.  The woman wears a turtleneck sweater and a fur lined greatcoat.  She also wears a shoulder bag (purse).  The second clipping is from The New Yorker.  Handwritten is "9/4/78".  There is a photograph of a woman in a water repellent cotton / polyester poplin jacket entirely lined in looks-like-real shearling.  The jacket has dog leash closings and a snuggly shawl collar.  It comes in camel or mocha brown and costs $130.  The third clipping is from the Classique Section of The Cincinnati Enquirer, September 12, 1978.  Cashin's name is underlined in red in this clipping.  There is a drawing of a woman in a storm coat in tan, made of heavyweight polyester / cotton poplin and warmly lined.  It also has natural raccoon trim at the hood, brass clasps, and a front tie belt to keep out the cold.  It costs $300.

Title: Page 31a
AltTitle.other: Cashin on fashion|~|Let it rain; you'll shine in "weatherwear"!
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (The Sunday Post, Bridgeport, September 10, 1978) is an advertisement for "creative Fall coatings by Bonnie Cashin for Russ Taylor" at Read's.  There is a drawing of a singe-breasted canvas coat with a red flannel liner ($170) and matching scarf.  There is also a drawing of a poncho with a drawstring waist and snap closing ($160).  The second clipping (Cadence, East Grand Rapids, Michigan, September 6, 1978) is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin's weatherwear collection.  There is a drawing of a woman in a long Cashin coat.  She also wears a hat.

Title: Page 31b
AltTitle.other: Designer collection Elnora Worder
Description.note: 4 clippings, likely all related or from same source.  The first (possibly the cover?) has a list of designers, including Cashin, and says "Designer Collection Elnora Worder."  The second clipping shows a woman in a natural and red coat, with a zebra tote bag and a zebra umbrella.  There is a brief caption describing the items and their prices.  The third clipping has captions for the image on third clipping as well as the fourth clipping.  The photograph in the third clipping is of a carmel/heather beige jacket and a solid polyester umbrella with Bonnie Cashin signature on one panel and coordinated suede-like handle in linen.  The fourth clipping features a bone beige/sand coat and a giant solid color shoulder strap tote with Bonnie Cashin screened signature.  The fourth clipping is in color.

Title: Page 32
AltTitle.other: Add fun and warmth to the coldest day with Bonnie Cashin's "creature comforter"|~|Weatherwear trunk show-- of her original Bonnie Cashin designs
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from Drummer, Philadelphia, PA, October 17, 1978.  There is a photograph of a woman in a quilted coat made of very strong typewriter ribbon nylon and worn in full bubble shape over slim quilted boot pants.  The second clipping is an advertisement for a one day only Cashin trunk show at Jaffe's.  There is a brief article about Cashin's design philosophy.  There are also accompanying sketches of a canvas lined coat with fake fox, and a hand knitted sweater jacket.

Title: Page 33
AltTitle.other: Raindrops keep falling...
Description.note: One clipping, from Johnson City, TN, Morn. Press- Chronicle, October 8, 1978.  The article deals with Bonnie Cashin's collection of rainy day clothes for Russ Taylor.  The first image and caption deals with quilties: Cashin's featherweight nylon quilted coat paired with matching quiltie bloomers.  The second look is a rainsuit made of ginger and poplin neutral in a full blown "petal jacket" over "Gringo" pants.  The third look is a paisley velveteen "bellweather" coat with a hood and a front-tie. The fourth look is a red poncho with simulated raccoon lining by Glenoit.

Description.note: One clipping, possibly from the Detroit Free Press, March 25, 1979, though unclear if there is any relationship between the clipping and the smaller clipping which just features that source and date.  The main clipping is an advertisement for Cashin's All Weather Coats at Crwoley's.  There is a drawing of a woman in a coat and hat, with a dog.

AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin creates with consumer in mind.

The article discusses Bonnie Cashin's work with ponchos.The other clipping is from The Jewish News--New Jersey from September 21, 1978.  This clipping features an image of poncho that is "unmistakably Bonnie Cashin" from her new Weatherwear collection for Russ Taylor.

Title: Page 36
AltTitle.other: Wrap up in style
Description.note: One clipping.  From Suburban News, October 4, 1978.  Handwritten on the side "Westfield N. Jersey."  Full page of a newspaper featuring a variety of advertisements and articles.  Article "Toni's Talk about Fashion" deals with coats.  Cashin's "Weatherwear" coat with fine detailing and workmanship is pictured.  The coat features big roomy pockets with industrial zippers and a "hardware" fastenings.  There is also a fringed scarf and the coat is done in Zepel finished cotton duck poplin.

Title: Page 37
AltTitle.other: Red-y for any weather|~|Deep-freeze wear
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from Harper's Bazaar, October 1978.  There is a photograph of a woman in a patterned coat with fur cuffs and collar.  The woman also wears a (newsboy?) cap and a scarf.  The second clipping is from October 15, 1978 from Charleston, South Carolina.  There is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin clothing at Daisy Bagin.  A coat of Cashin's is featured in a drawing.  The coat is canvas with side entry pockets, wool blend linter/matching stole scarf, and comes in off white/red and red/camel.  The third clipping is from the Buffalo, New York Courier-Express, September 8, 1978.  There is a brief caption and a photograph of a featherweight nylon quiltie big coat with a hood.  There are also matching quiltie bloomers.

Title: Page 38
AltTitle.other: Vitality: healthy good looks at any age|~|Bazaar's fashion guide
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first (possibly from Harper's Bazaar?) is from a section called "Beauty Bazaar" and entitled "Vitality: Healthy Good Looks At Any Age."  There is a photograph of a woman ("Sporty Susanna") in a turtleneck sweater and trousers on a bicycle with a child riding in a seat on the back.  Handwritten in red is "Bonnie Cashin" with an arrow pointing to the sweater.  Also written in red in the bottom right corner is "Oct '78 HB."  The second clipping is the Bazaar's Fashion Guide from October 1978.  Handwritten in red is "Bonnie Cashin" near Cashin's name in the Guide.  The third clipping is a handwritten note that reads "Bonnie-- Some nerve hiding your name in the back!" There is also a signature that is illegible.  The note is dated 10/7/78.

AltTitle.other: Paris and New York hemming and hawing
Description.note: One clipping, from Knoxville, Tenn. News-Sentinel, November 19, 1978.  Article by Marian Christy about rising skirt hemlines.  There are accompanying photographs of a variety of designers including Ungaro.  There is a photograph of a Bonnie Cashin puddle-jumper skirt that is short, pleated, and rain-resistant.  The woman in the photograph also wears rainboots (with a heel), a loose-fitting jacket, and a hat.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|fur|~|toggles
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 48
AltTitle.other: Our new Bonnie Cashin fashion looks smashin' under the following weather conditions:
Description.note: One clipping, from The New York Times, November 16, 1978.  Advertisement for Cashin Weatherwear for the Russ Taylor Company at Baltman & Co.  There is a drawing of a woman in the coat.  The coat has easy raglan sleeves, a soft tie belt, and a hood richly ringed with natural raccoon fur.  The outside of the coat is a sturdy canvas of polyester and cotton.  The inside of the coat is a pile lining of polyester, acrylic, and modacrylic.  There are also snappy hardware metal toggles, roomy outside pockets, and a secret inside pocket.  The coat costs $300 and protects against "fog, mist, drizzle, mizzle, and guggles of rain."

There is a handwritten note in pencil on the top left corner that reads "B.c. Thought you'd be interested" with an illegible signature.

Subject: hoods (headgear)|~|trousers|~|raincoats|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 52
AltTitle.other: What goes on: Bonnie Cashin envelops a wide, wonderful world|~|Fashion designer addresses woman's club
Description.note: Two clippings.  One article from Mamroneck, N.Y. Times, November 23, 1978.  This article discusses Cashin's speech to the Woman's Club of Larchmont.  Cashin discussed the role of women, and fashion's relationship to women and their roles.  The second clipping is from the Columbus, Ohio Citizen-Journal, November 6, 1978.  This article discusses Cashin's designs and passion for fashion.  There is a photograph of a woman in a Bonnie Cashin rainsuit in her Weatherwear Collection for Russ Taylor that combines ginger and turf poplin in full blown "petal jacket" over slim "grinko" pants.  The woman also wears a hat, a hood, and rainboots with a heel.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 53

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 54
AltTitle.other: It's here, it's now, it's coyote
Description.note: One clipping.  Advertisement for Bonnie Cashin fur coats at Rein, Rame & Gurvitch, Inc. in New York.  There is a photograph of a woman in a fur coat, with a knit hat and knit gloves.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: jackets (garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|turtleneck sweaters--1970-1980|~|fur
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 55
AltTitle.other: Outstanding fur silhouettes
Description.note: One clipping.  From Childress, Texas Index, August 29, 1978.  Brief article describing Cashin's Fur Collection for Rein, Rame & Gurvitch.  There are three sketches above the text.  They show: a Noh coat that is available in Lunaraine mink or natural feathered raccoon; a hooded cape in silver fox; and a bubble coat in red fox.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: sweaters--1970-1980
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 56
AltTitle.other: Sounding off: Cashin and 'the knit corps'
Description.note: One clipping.  From The Washington Star, December 10, 1978.  There is a photograph of Cashin, as well as a sketch of Cashin's showing a thick knotty sweater.  The article discusses Cashin's love of knits and her Knittery.  She also notes that she would like to begin a project that would teach knitting to "idle but useful hands" such as those "alone at home, in hospitals,... in penitentiaries, and... of the handicapped."  She hopes for government backing and a smart young visionary business manager-organizer to help realize this vision.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 57a
AltTitle.other: The working woman|~|Dieting was never so sweet
Description.note: Two clippings.  One has a variety of quotations from working women.  The other is an advertisement for Figurines dieting bars.  Cashin is not mentioned in either clipping.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 57b
AltTitle.other: The working woman
Description.note: One clipping.  Two pages from a magazine.  There is a quotation from Bonnie Cashin circled in pen: "from Thoreau I learned, 'Don’t worry when you stumble— remember a worm is the only thing that can’t fall down.” If you're doing creative work you know how true that is. You must be exploratory, be unafraid of making a mist— or you'll never get beyond yourself.'"

AltTitle.other: Return of the hand knits...
Description.note: One clipping.  The article discusses hand knit sweaters.  The source of the materials used is discussed, and Cashin, whose name is underlined in red, is noted as having sources in Iceland and the Irish coast.  One of Cashin's Icelandic wool sweaters is shown: a beige and grey striped cardigan sweater with a hood ($120).

Title: Page 60
AltTitle.other: Day in, night out by Covers|~|Just for "her"
Description.note: One clipping.  From Modern Living, December 12, 1978.  Advertisement for Cashin at Madaras Fashion Center in Stowe.  There are two sketches of Cashin designs.  The shows a coat from the Bonnie Cashin Coat Collection.  The coat has a tie in front.  The second drawing is from the Bonnie Cashin Weatherwear for Russ Taylor collection.  There is a drawing of an elegant Qiana coat, light as a feather, rich as a jewel.  The coat is machine washable and fully lined.  It is protected with Sil-Kote weatherproof finish and the added feature of DuPont Zepel Rain/Stain.

It also has brass turnlock [turnscrew] closures and roomy patch pockets.  It costs $160.  The woman is also show with a red purse with pockets on the outside.

In the center image, one woman wears a Bonnie Cashin 100% wool handknit sweater from Scotland in an ivory/brown combination with leather ties.  It is one size fits all and costs $300.  There is also a hand crocheted and woven mohair and wool evening sweater that comes in white or black.  It is also one size fits all.  It costs $350.  The price is circled in and there is an arrow pointing at the sweater.  It does not say Bonnie Cashin though.

The second clipping is from the Philadelphia Inquirer, September 24, 1978.  This clipping is an advertisement for the Bonnie Cashin Fall Weatherwear Collection at Nan Duskin.  There is a photograph of a woman in a greatcoat, and a turtleneck sweater stretched into a hood.

There is a drawing of a Bonnie Cashin weatherwear coat for rain adn cold with furry lining and drawing waist.  It also has a hood, and costs $200.  The second clipping is for Bonnie Cashin Weatherwear for Russ Taylor at Bullock's.  There is a drawing of a woman in a Qiana ultra light rain coat taht comes in natural or peachy-beige.  It costs $150.

Description.note: One clipping, source and date unknown.  Advertisement for Bonnie Cashin clothing at Jordan Marsh.  There is a drawing of a woman in a fantastical flare coat made of a dazzle of silky Qiana nylon to float through rainy days or dramatize important nights.  The coat is fully lined, with its own attached scarf to wrap or tie in a bow.  The coat comes in oyster, cafe au lait, or sable and costs $130.

There is a drawing of a woman in an elegant Qiana coat, light as a feather, rich as a jewel. And wonderfully machine washable. Here in the new tent fullness, with a soft flow of scarf. Fully lined with hand bound button holes. Protected with Sil-Kote weatherproof finish and with the added feature of DuPont ZEPEL Rain/Stain Repeller. Natural, Silver Blue, Black. Sizes 6 to 16, about $125.

AltTitle.other: Cashin fashion wraps up a world of wearable coats
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Lexington, Kentucky Leader, August 25, 1978.  Article discussing Cashin's cold weather clothes.  Her coats and ponchos are described as wearable and warm.  Cashin says that she thinks of "herself as a consumer when she designs" which "helps keep the price down and the quality up."  Her Knittery designs are also discussed.  Two of her photographs are shown accompanying the article.  One is Cashin's featherweight, nylon-quilted coat big enough to envelop all the sweaters and jackets you'll wear for winter warmth.  There are also matching quilted bloomers for fashion flair.  The other outfit shown is a bright red poplin poncho with simulated raccoon made by Glenoit with deep pockets, a face-framing hood, and hardware fastenings.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|fur|~|raccoon
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 101
AltTitle.other: Pick protection by the season
Description.note: One clipping.  Date and source unknow.  Article from Dorothy Dale's Fashion World column.  The article discusses various protections your body needs during summer and winter, primarily sunblock and fur.  There are two photographs of women in Cashin furs.  The first shows a feathered raccoon smock coat.  It is voluminous, enveloping, and comfortable and light as elderdown.  The second photograph shows the ulitmate in luxury: Cashin's flurry of pure white fox floor length hooded coat.  The richness of the fur is complimented by full sleeves and the body cut to show it to best advantage.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 102
AltTitle.other: Revillon Furs present presents two more winter styles
Description.note: One clipping.  Paper above clipping says "Brockton, MASS.  Enterprise & Times" and stamped "JUL 28 1978".  There is a photograph of a man in a woman in Revillon Furs.  She wears a new style in raccoon and he wears a dyed otter coat with raccoon collar.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 103
AltTitle.other: Furry friends
Description.note: One clipping.  The paper above the clipping says "Dallas, Texas News" and stamped "JUL 20 1978".  It is unclear if this is the date that the clipping is from since the caption beneath the picture in the clipping discusses the recent cold weather necessitating fur coats.  There is a photograph of two women in Cashin fur coats.  One wears a feathered raccoon coat, and the other wears a red fox coat.  These coats are being shown in a three day showing in Dallas.

AltTitle.other: The shoulders wide...
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Lancaster, PA. Sunday News, Jun. 25, 1978.  Photograph of a woman in a Bonnie Cashin "duck hunter's" jacket that features a shearling-look lining and a cotton canvas outshell.  There are also hardware fastenings, multi-pockets, and slim trousers with industrial zipper pockets.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: dresses (garments)|~|trousers|~|frogs (fasteners)|~|alpaca (fiber)|~|raincoats|~|coats (garments)|~|shirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 23b
AltTitle.other: Idea girl|~|Loaf as you like in garb you fancy|~|Neiman-Marcus point of view
Description.note: Five clippings.  Cashin's name is underlined in hot pink in each clipping.  The first clipping has article that discusses knitting and knits.  The history of knitting is briefly discussed as well as the modern woman's distate for it.  Cashin's unusual collection of knits is also discussed.  The second clipping also has Cashin's name underlined in hot pink.  There is a drawing of a woman in a dress and a jacket and a photograph of a woman (Cashin?) in a dress (?).  This clipping has a brief anecdote about Cashin losing a suitcase in Italy but still being the bressed dress woman on board her ship.  This anecdote is used to illustrate Cashin's fashion philosophy.  The third clipping shows a woman in a tweed and alpaca coat that has been treated for water resistance.  It is by Bonnie Cashin for Main Street.  The fourth clipping shows a luxurious at home gown of cotton shot with lurex threads and a velvet sash with ball fringe that hugs the waist.  The dress has a stand-away collar that frames the face with flattery.  The fifth clipping is from the Mobile, Alabama Press, October 22, 1952.  It shows an "Alice-sit-by-the-fire" with "alluring Oriental overtones".  The at-home separates are made of pure silk honan designed by Cashin.  There are slim tapering trousers topped by a reversible coat with frogs (fasteners).

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: bed jackets|~|pillowcases|~|dresses (garments)|~|coats (garments)|~|robes (main garments)|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 24a
AltTitle.other: Jacket and pillow slip match|~|Stay-at-home clothes in high style|~|Idea girl : Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: Six clippings.  The first is a continuation of a clipping from  21198/zz00088w2t.  This clipping discusses Cashin, her personality, her designs, and her business.  Cashin's childhood in Los Angeles is also discussed.  The second clipping is a very short clipping noting Cashin's knitwear at Lord & Taylor.  The third clipping only shows the sentences in the clipping surrounding Cashin's name.  This clipping has something to do with "Night at Opera" fashions.  The fourth clipping shows a woman in a "Fireside Gown" in silk and rayon dressed up with velvet trimming.  It is crisply made with short blown-up sleeves and full skirt.  It is made for hostessing and comfortable evenings at home.  It costs "under seventy".  The fifth clipping shows a bed jacket and matching pillow slip designed by Bonnie Cashin for Stella Fagin.  The set is shown in quilted, flower-sprigged sheer with a choice of pink or blue posies on a white background.  The ruffled pillow-slip has a convenient pocket, and the jacket fastens with pretend pearl buttons and boasts two pockets.  The sixth clipping shows a dress with a billowy skirt of nylon tulle with color under black.  The dress separates "that love live after-five".

Title: Page 11b
AltTitle.other: Hikers' heaven|~|Invitation to walk
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is an advertisement for British Walkers shoes.  There are two drawings of shoes (the "Canterbury" and the "Norfolk").  There is also a photograph of a woman with a dog in a hat, a jacket, and a skirt.  It is unclear if Cashin is featured in this clipping in any way.  Handwritten in pencil below the clipping is "March Vogue".  The second clipping is also an advertisement for British Walkers.  There is a photograh of a woman in a hat, a jacket, a skirt, and the British Walkers shoes.  The "Meadowbrook" and the "Fairway" shoes are also featured in drawing form.  Below the clipping is handwritten in pencil "April Vogue".  It is unclear if Cashin is involved in this clipping at all.

Title: Page 16b
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from an unknown source.  There is a photograph of five women with headwraps and in Rosie the Riveter poses.  It is unclear if Cashin's designs are featured in this photograph at all.  What is shown: high-cut green suede slacks ($29.95); pink suede shirt ($16.95); Martha West Norwegian cotton slacks, shirt, and jacket ($16.75); Abercombie & Fitch Natural linen slacks; striped East-Indian cotton sashed shirt ($30-something dollars, price is covered by second clipping); Farr Alpaca slacks, cardigan, skirt (not shown), ($19.95); Jane Engel Navy wool slacks ($18.75); and a long-sleeved striped shirt ($9.75).  The second clipping has a photograph of a woman in a hat and a tweed coat.  The coat is by Adler & Adler.  There is no mention of Cashin.  Handwritten on the side of this clipping is "J + C.--" [not quite sure, possibly "T + C"?].

Description.note: Three clippings.  Source and date unknown.  The first clipping shows a woman exiting a plane in a dress.  The caption reads "Mrs. Brewster Gillies, of Long Islan, President of the 99 Club".  The second clipping shows a woman in a plaid dress, and gloves and a hat.  The caption notes that the dress is made of a Glenurquhart plaid-- blue and russet on beige rayon and silk.  THe dress costs about $25 and is available at Henri Bendel.  The third clipping shows a woman in a plaid, pleated skirt and jacket suit.  She also wears a hat.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 22a

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|stripes|~|dresses (garments)|~|shirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 23a
Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten below the photograph is "May 40 Harpers".  At the left top of the photograph is "Abot $30. Bonwit Teller -- L.S. Ayers, Indianapolis -- I. Magnin, California" and the right corner says "Louise Dahl-Wolfe".  There is a photograph of a woman in a striped dress with a matching shirt (short-sleeved jacket?).  The woman also wears a belt.  It is unclear if Cashin is involved.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|dresses (garments)|~|gloves|~|coats (garments)|~|shirts|~|hats|~|pleats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 23b
AltTitle.other: This habitmaker goes South|~|Start Summer in cool, cool linen!
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first is [possibly?] from Harper's Bazaar.  There is a photograph of a woman in a sheer French linen in cool sea green.  The woman also wears gloves and holds a hat.  There is an ivy pattern around the photograph.  The second clipping says at the top of the clipping "Reprinted from TOWN & COUNTRY, December 1940".  There is a photograph of a woman in a dress called the Habitmaker.  The Habitmaker is a sports dress made with famous comfort-giving "Free Action Sleeves."  The dress is made of Oxford crepe of Celanese rayon and silk and comes in Orleans blue, brick pink, and cotton white.  It costs $25.  The third clipping is also of the Habitmake with Free Action Sleeves.  On the top of the clipping it reads "Reprinted from TOWN & COUNTRY, December 1939".  This Habitmaker is a two-piece, but also made of Oxford crepe and with "Free Action Sleeves."  It costs $35.  The fourth clipping is a photograph of a woman in a scarf / headband and a coat.  Handwritten in pencil on the left of the clipping is "Vogue".

Title: Page 39b
Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten on the bottom left corner of the picture is "Oct Harpers".  There is a photograph of a woman reclining on grass in a long-sleeve dress [shirt and skirt?] with interesting fastenings, a pleat in the front of the skirt, and a belt.  Next to the woman is either a hat or a bag.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|dresses (garments)|~|gloves|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 40a
Description.note: One clipping.  Source and date unknown.  On the bottom left of the picture is "Oct WA" [written very, very lightly; not quite sure].  There is a photograph of a woman in a matching jacket and dress.  The dress and jacket has a diamond and square pattern on it.  She also wears gloves and a hat with a veil attached.  It is unclear if Cashin is the designer or not.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|jackets (garments)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 40b
AltTitle.other: Miss Peggy Stevenson
Description.note: One clipping.  On the bottom left is handwritten "Oct. Camels".  Advertisement for Camel cigarettes featuring charming golfer from the North Shore of Long Island, Peggy Stevenson.  Peggy Stevenson is is the lovely daughter of the Philip Stevensons of Glen Cove, Long Island.  Stevenson wears a "comfy" woolen jacket for golf, as well as a skirt with pleats.  It is unclear if the outfit is a Cashin design.  Stevenson discusses her preference for Camels and why.  She notes their mildness and how they boost her energy.  Camels notes that "Camels never get on your nerves."

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|dresses (garments)|~|gloves|~|hats|~|pleats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 41a
AltTitle.other: Forecast|~|The compleat suit
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from Hockanum.  There is a photograph of a woman in a dress with a long, slim silhouette with pleats on the bottom of the skirt.  She also wears a hat.  It is unclear if it is a Cashin design.  The second clipping has a red "x" next to it and "1943" is handwritten.  There is a photograph of a woman in a "compleat" suit, with a skirt with pleats.  The woman also wears a lap robe, a checked cocoa-brown Stroock wool collarless jacket, a hat, gloves, and a cape.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|dresses (garments)|~|shirts|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 41b
AltTitle.other: It's an Altman Meadowbrook
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is an advertisement for B. Altman & Co.  THere is a photograph of a woman in a dress and a hat.  It is unclear if it is a Cashin design or not.  The second clippling is a drawing of a woman in a bonnet, a saddle-stitched top, and a skirt.  The shirt and skirt are made of black wool jersey and the outfit costs $29.95 and is available at Bonwit Teller.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: stripes|~|dresses (garments)|~|headcloths (headgear)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 42
Description.note: One clipping.  Photograhp of a woman in a striped dress that ties like a bow at the neck.  She also wears a headcloth and sunglasses.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 1
Description.note: One clipping.  A pink, yellow, and green roses.  It is unclear if it is a Cashin design.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: evening dresses (garments)|~|stripes|~|gloves|~|maxiskirts|~|coats (garments)--1940-1950|~|playsuits
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 2a
Description.note: One clipping.  From The New York Times Magazine, October 11, 1942.  Clipping showing contrasting wartime styles.  The first photograph shows a costume by Bonnie Cashin (whose name is underlined in red) for the symbolical girl of the future.  Cashin's design for the girl of the future wears a tunic suit [playsuit?] for play and work, permitting her plenty of freedom of action, for the girl of the future will be tall and strong.  On top of the tunic suit is a coat of fabric of long-enduring quality.  The costume is blue with a coat of red and white.  The second photograph has Cashin written in pencil next to the design, but does not seem to be a Cashin design.  It is an evening gown.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|stripes|~|checker pattern|~|dresses (garments)|~|cloches (hats)|~|shirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 2b
Description.note: One clipping.  From The New York Times Magazine, December 20, 1942.  There is some yellow on the bottom of the page in a drawing, possibly drawn in or possibly part of the printed page.  There are two photographs featuring three women.  There is only design by Cashin.  Cashin's design is a black rayon crepe bodice with a raspberry pink skirt with "market basket" pockets.  There are also a couple dresses and skirts and shirts shown by other designers.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 3a

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: coats (garments)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 3b
Description.note: One clipping.  On the left side of the clipping is a red check mark.  There is a photograph of two women in coats.  They both also wear hats.  It is unclear what Cashin designed in the photograph.  One of the coats is a gray coat lined with berry-red silk of the dress beneath.  The other is black.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 4a
AltTitle.other: Morning in Havana
Description.note: One clipping.  The clipping is entitled "Morning in Havana" and around the title is a sketch of Cuba and a couple boats.  It is unclear if there are any Cashin designs in this clipping.  What is pictured: a dress by Jay Thrope; shorts cut like a boy's and a jersey shirt by Best; a coat by Jay Thorpe; and a coat by Abercombie and Fitch.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 44a
AltTitle.other: Uniform Agreement
Description.note: One clipping.  This clipping has an article describing the design of a RCA women's uniform.  Bonnie Cashin was involved in this effort, alongside Marjorie Holligan (fabric expert and stylist for Celanese Corporation of America), Nancy Copeland and Ruth Nelson (CHARM editors), and Helen Bircher (Employment Manger of the RCA plant).  There is also a photograph of Cashin and Bircher looking over designs.

Subject: cardigans|~|halters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|stripes|~|sunsuits|~|trousers|~|umbrellas|~|jump suits
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 8b
AltTitle.other: Brightly colored torso sweaters are popular with casual attire|~|Dorothy Neighbors: fashions|~|Knits are nice and new-looking
Description.note: Five clippings.  The first (Kansas City, MO., Star, June 28, 195?) is a brief article noting that Bonnie Cashin was a speaker at a luncheon meeting.  The second clipping has a photograph of a woman in trousers and a knit halter.  There is also an article discussing Bonnie Cashin's "knit addiction."The third clipping (The New York Times, June 24, 1953) is a photograph of a woman sitting on her kness in a Bonnie Cashin sleeveless hooded white pullover.  The fourth clipping (Seattle Wn. Times, May 31, 1953-- also written above the image: "Exs 382 Miss Latta") has a photograph of a sitting woman in a Bonnie Cashin striped wool sunsuit.The fifth clipping (handwritten: "Trenton, NJ Trentonian," July 17, 1953) has a photograph of a woman in a striped wool cardigan.  The accompanying article discusses the rediscovery of wool for summer wear.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|suits (main garments)|~|scarves (costume accessories)|~|cardigans|~|tweed|~|dresses (garments)|~|leather|~|fur|~|gloves|~|coats (garments)|~|shirts|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 15a
AltTitle.other: Night leathers|~|White leather shirt
Description.note: Six clippings.  There are also a variety of a small clippings noting where the main clippings have come from (?).  The first clipping is in color and shows a slender, urban two-piece dress.  The dress is a handsome street costume worn either with or without a coat.  It is made of a wool novelty-knit with a slashed neckline bound in contrasting trim with a narrow self sash-belt.  It is also available in ruby red with gold, black with gray, or blue with turquoise.  It costs about $50.  The second clipping shows an elegantly slender column, newly knit of heavy wool from neck to hem.  The silhouette is faintly high-waisted, and the collar just a little stand-offish.  It comes in black or blue and costs $39.95.  The third clipping is in color and shows a barred tweed knit dress with a slot neckline, bracelet sleeves, and pencil skirt.  The fourth clipping has "Sills" handwritten on the left side of the photograph.  This clipping shows a Cashin black antelope coat.  Above the clipping is a small clipping that says "Look  Des Moines, Iowa".  To the left of the clipping is a small clipping that says "A Good Housekeeping facts first fashion".  The fifth clipping shows Jane Hill, '53, wearing a heavy, close-knit wool jacket (cardigan?) buttoned down the front and belted in back.  The sixth clipping shows a woman in a white leather shirt of goatskin with deep pockets, stitched seams and a silk scarf.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|belts (costume accessories)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|tweed|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|leather|~|alpaca (fiber)|~|coats (garments)|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 16a
AltTitle.other: A new 'leather stopper' -- designed by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin for Sills & Company.  The text notes that Cashin's designs are seen in the editorial pages of August 15 Vogue.  There is a woman in a large leather coat, a tweed skirt, a turtleneck, and holding a cow fur and leather bag (?).  There are also four belts floating on the right side of the page.  The second clipping shows a woman in a black capeskin coat with a squared collar, big pockets, and alpaca lining.  She also wears a hat.  There is another woman in a hat as well.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 16b

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: cardigans|~|coats (garments)--1950-1960|~|berets|~|leather|~|trousers|~|fur|~|gloves|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 17a
AltTitle.other: New York's topflight designers tell truth about Dior's skirt|~|Political fashion show|~|Capeskin|~|Cherries bright|~|Fashion spotlights leather|~|Stampede?
Description.note: Eight clippings.  Additionally in the upper right corner there is a list of various newspapers: Midland, Mich. News; New York Post; Endicott, N.Y., Bulletin; Bangor, ME. Commercial; San Francisco, Calif., Chronicle; San Francisco, Cal., Examiner.  The first clipping (Boston, Mass., American, Aug. 11, 1953) discusses Cashin's innovative use of leather in her designs.  There is also a photograph of a woman in a long leather coat with a fur collar.  She also wears a hat.  There is another accompanying photo of a woman in a different coat and hat.  She also wears gloves.  The second clipping also shows a photograph of a  woman in a long coat and hat.  The fourth clipping is a brief text also describing Cashin's use of leather.  The fourth clipping (Davenport, Iowa Times) has two photographs and a brief caption.  The photographs show: a woman in a long coat and hat (same photo as in second clipping), and a woman in cardigan, beret, and skirt.  The fifth clipping (Boston, Mass., American, Oct. 16, 1953) shows a woman eating cherries in pants and with a cardigan draped over her shoulders.  The sixth clipping is a headline (Detroit, Mich., News, Aug. 2, 1953) that reads "New York's Topflight Designers Tell Truth About Dior's Skirt."  The seventh clipping might be the text to the headline, as it discusses Cashin's take on Dior's skirt.  The eighth clipping (N.Y. World-Telegram & Sun, Oct. 22, 1953) discusses Cashin's participation in a fashion show and luncheon in honor of a NY Republication Mayor Candidate's wife.

Title: Page 26b
AltTitle.other: In America this Spring: leather and leather - colours|~|This is luxury
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is in color and from an unknown source.  This clippings shows a glove-leather sheath dress made of kidskin.  It costs $75.  The second clipping has handwritten above the caption "Lord + Taylor".  The photograph shows Mrs. H. Whitfield Carhart, Jr., in a suede topcoat designed by Cashin on the lines of a man's shirt with a button-down collar, square pockets, front panel and all.  The third clipping shows a woman in a leather shirt by Cashin.  It is available in paprika, tobacco, turf green, avocado or burnt almond suede.  It costs $49.95.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 30a
AltTitle.other: The stylized skirt created by Bonnie Cashin for Bendel ... a dramatic fashion for holiday wearing|~|A designer
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from The Milwaukee Journal, March 7, 1954.  There is a color photograph of Cashin in a blue dress and knitting.  Cashin is described as wearing her own fashions.  Some of her own designs she has worn are noted.  The second clipping (possibly a continuation of the same article?) discusses Cashin's practical and colorful designs.  The third clipping is an advertisement for Cashin at Henri Bendel's.  There are three drawings of Cashin designs.  The clipping shows: a tie-waisted iridescent wool tweed button-front with two mammoth pockets ($69.95); a dinner skirt of silver-threaded nubby black-and-white tweed with a peg top circled with an elasticized wrap-around velvet belt ($155); scoop-neck cashmere sweater ($35); and a "graph paper" saddle-stitched white-on-grey flannel slim-liner with a high-rising belt ($39.95).

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|leather|~|trousers|~|cloches (hats)|~|sleeveless tops|~|sweaters|~|gloves|~|coats (garments)|~|shirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Name.manufacturer: Sills and Company|~|E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company
Title: Page 30b
AltTitle.other: Independents, U.S.A.|~|Printed leather shirt jacket|~|Leather in the limelight
Description.note: Three clippings.  There are also one small clipping that says "Du Pont 'Zelan'".  The first clipping is an advertisement for Cashin at Henri Bendel's.  There are drawings of women in leather.  The garments shown are: a kidskin duo of a fingertip jacket ($85) and hem length coat ($155) with vent back, and shirt cuffs; duck canvas and kidskin skirt ($25), pants ($29.95), and drawstring hooded jacket ($59.95).  The second clipping is from The Milwaukee Journal and shows a printed leather shirt jacket in black on red and designed by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills.  The woman in the photograph also wears a black knitted dress and a deep black velvet cloche.  Handwritten on the left of "[illegible] '55".  The third clipping shows an apron-skirt (can be an apron or a skirt; $40) in leather-bound beige duck and a sleeveless olive green sweater, heavy-knitted in wool ($11).

Subject: suits (main garments)|~|scarves (costume accessories)|~|jackets (garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|shorts (garments)|~|tweed|~|silk (textile)|~|cummerbunds|~|suede|~|maxiskirts|~|shirts|~|hats|~|pleats

Title: Page 35a
AltTitle.other: Tumbleweed suede|~|Travel ensemble|~|Pink earth (color of Arizona soil)|~|Airplane age fashions hail Spring at Idlewild|~|Rainy day dashes hopes
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first has three photographs of women in Cashin styles.  These photograph outfits show: a pink earth colored suede dinner skirt with cumberbund [cummerbund]; blue haze suede shorts and jacket; and dusty gray-beige shirt with fringed belt with collar, sleeves, and pleated skirt in printed tie skil by Brooke Cadwaller (it is unclear if Cashin is associated with this outfit).  The second clipping shows a woman in a full-length black and white tweed cape with a matching skirt.  The third clipping has no images and is from The Detroit News, January 2, 1955.  It discusses Cashin's travel collection for Siggy.  The collection includes travel-minded suits and coats aimed straight at America's growing colony of feminine commuters and globe-trotters.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|coats (garments)--1950-1960|~|sweaters--1950-1960|~|hobble skirts|~|umbrellas|~|gloves|~|raincoats|~|suede|~|plaids|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 35b
AltTitle.other: Eastman Estron through the hours
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from The Milwaukee Journal, July 10, 1955.  This clipping shows a woman in a suede suit.  The suit has a blue pencil skirt with a matching coat of the same length.  The coat has green knit trim that matches the sweater beneath the sweater.  The woman also holds gloves that match the suit.  The second clipping shows a woman in a Cashin for Harris Raincoat Company raincoat.  The raincoat is plaid.  The woman also wears a hat and holds an umbrella.  The raincoat and the matching hat cost under $30.

Title: Page 8b
AltTitle.other: Country elegance|~|Lounge by the fire|~|Come rain or shine
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first ("Bulletin"?, December 6, 1957) has two photographs of women in Bonnie Cashin robes.  One robe is wool, the other has a floral print.The second clipping is a photograph of a woman in the apartment of famed weaver Dorothy Liebes.  The woman in this photo wears a Bonnie Cashin red, green, and yellow plaid mohair skirt with fringed hems.The third clipping has a photograph of a blond and white Bonnie Cashin striped rain coat.  The woman also holds an umbrella.

Title: Page 18b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie designer blazes fashion trails others follow eagerly|~|Playbill fashions: cult of the casual
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (Chicago Sunday Tribune, January 12, 1958) has an article alongside a photograph of Bonnie Cashin and sketches of some examples from her Spring collection for Philip Sills.  The article includes Cashin's description of the her credo.The second clipping describes a weightless, spongy, springy mohair coat alongside a sketch of the coat.  The coat is $95.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 20a
AltTitle.other: Manhattan preview!|~|'Half-and-half' coats mix leather, fabric
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from The Detroit News, December 31, 1956.  This clipping has two photographs of women in Cashin designs.  One photograph shows a coat by Cashin in caramel suede with capelike front panels and matching skirt of sooty cognac tweed with belted front panels that cross over surplice style or may be worn straight.  The other photograph shows a Cashin for Philip Sills coat with an ivory kidskin front with round collar, sleeves, flared back and set-in hipband of matching curly chinchilla wool.  This article discusses Cashin's suede and kidskin leather fashions.  One of Cashin's West German models is also discussed.  The second clipping discusses printed leather.  The third clipping may accompany the second clipping.  It is a photograph of a woman in a jacket of printed leather.

AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills Inc
Description.note: One clipping.  Advertisement featuring images of a gold, red, and pink crocodile, cheetah, and cow.  Text in center says "Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills Inc."  The advertisement invites interested parties to make an appointment to view Cashin's Resort and Spring collection (beginning Oct. 27).

Title: Page 7
AltTitle.other: American Fabrics gallery of famous American designers|~|Bonnie Cashin's Clever Leather Capes|~|White by night
Description.note: 3 clippings.  The first (New York Herald Tribune, May 19, 1960) has two sketches of leather capes.  There is an accompanying article about the leather capes in Cashin's fall collection for Philip Sills.  The second clipping (New York Times Magazine, Oct 30, 1960) features a sketch of a white leather silk-lined sleeveless top an a fake-fur skirt for a gala evening in ski country.  The top and skirt are by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills.  The top costs $40, and the skirt is available on order.  The third clipping is from the American Fabrics Gallery of Famous American Designers.  There is an image of Bonnie Cashin and a caption praising her imaginative designs.

Subject: jackets (garments)|~|ponchos|~|coats (garments)--1960-1970|~|dresses (garments)--1960-1970|~|mohair|~|leather|~|raincoats|~|suede

Title: Page 10a
AltTitle.other: Cashin, Count Marco agree|~|Spring styles sho... [cut off]
Description.note: Two clippings.  Handwritten in the top right corner is "S.F. Chronicle - May 18 / 1963" San Francisco Chronicle.  This clipping Cashin discusses her feelings on the iconic little black dress.  There is a photograph of a woman in a Cashin poncho raincoat that unsnaps and folds.  It comes in red, orange, and olive green, and costs $46.  The second clipping is from the Fort Worth Star-Telegraph.  This article is cut off at the right side.  Three Cashin designs are shown.  Shown are: a geranium leather bib-top jacket by Cashin with an elasticized neckline and can be worn with the snap fastening down the back (worn over a jersey sheath that is not visible on top); a beige mohair coat buckled with a trap of taupe suede worn over a sleeveless shift of taupe suede which fastens over the shoulders; and a scalloped suede bateau neck dress.

Title: Page 34
AltTitle.other: On award streak|~|Bonnie Cashin : top designer|~|Five 1961 Coty Award winners
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first clipping is a photograph of Bonnie Cashin in a shorts and a checkered tunic.  Her numerous awards are noted in the caption.  The second clipping shows four photographs of awards winners.  There is a photograph of Cashin in a hat.  Her name is underlined and written beneath the photographs in red is "Her. Trib. June 21".  The third clipping has handwritten above "Detroit Free Press - May 2 /63".  There is a photograph of a woman in a Cashin layered look in a skirt of light blue jersey, and a matching leather shell lined with pink and blue plaid.  The shell is open in the back, almost like a vest worn backwards.  The woman also wears a hood.  There is also a photograph of Cashin and her name is underlined in the article, noting that she has been named "Designer of the Year."  The fourth clipping discusses the 1961 Coty Award Winners.

Title: Page 42b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin says: world around us inspires creative artist
Description.note: One clipping.  From The Philadelphia Inquirer, January 20, 1964.  Article: "Fashion in Living: Leading designers write exclusively for The Inquirer: Bonnie Cashin says: World around us inspires creative artist".  Article is by Bonnie Cashin.  Before the article there is short bit describing Cashin and her career.  The section of the article by Cashin discusses her source material and what inspires her.  There are a variety of sketches by Cashin, as well as a photograph of Cashin herself.  The sketches shown are: a flowing cape of handwoven tweed with leather tracing and a large leather clasp; a softly bloused suit of fluffy mohair in Venetian glass colorings; a coat in pale grey-green kidskin inspired by a French butcher's coat; and a brown and white check wool crepe tunic and skirt traced in pale rice leather.

Title: Page 44b
AltTitle.other: Leather leads the fashion parade
Description.note: One clipping.  From Rohm & Haas Reporter, March / April 1964.  There is a brief article discussing leather and the fashionableness of leather.  There are three photographs of women in fine grain "Angola" leather produced by Wood & Hyde Leather Company of Gloversville, New York.  They are all designed by Cashin.  One woman wears a tan leather dress with buttons (snaps?) down the top front of the dress and a matching leather head kerchief.  The second woman wears a darker leather cape and matching skirt.  She also wears a orange and brown striped top under the cape.  The third photograph shows a woman in a red leather top with soft red collar and cuffs.  The woman also wears a red skirt (unsure if leather or not) and a leather red head kerchief.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|pullovers|~|hoods (headgear)|~|artificial fur|~|leather|~|sweaters|~|mackinaws|~|short shorts|~|coats (garments)|~|suede
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 45a
AltTitle.other: The leather edged deep-country coat|~|The leather fashions|~|Vogue|~|Very Saks Fifth Avenue
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first has a Vogue cover behind the clipping.  There is a photograph of a woman in a double-breasted mackinaw coat ($110) and short shorts ($40) of ivory kidskin.  She also wears a hooded sweater of ivory wool jersey ($35), though only the hood of the sweater is visible.  These items are by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills.  The second clipping is from Women's Wear Daily, May 12, 1964.  There is a drawing of a woman in a putty suede pullover and a smooth leather skirt.  Leather is used to trim the suede top.  The outfit is by Cashin for Philip Sills.  The third clipping is an advertisement for Cashin at Saks Fifth Avenue.  There is a drawing of a woman (with a dalmatian dog) in a faux fur coat cropped to three-quarter length and shaped like a giant caridgan framed and cuffed with leather, in black mod-acrylic pile.  It costs $135.

Title: Page 58b
AltTitle.other: Mrs. Heriberto S. Lobo|~|Leather: pastel pretty for Spring with bold textured woolens
Description.note: Two clippings.  One features a large photograph of Mrs. Heriberto S. Lobo wearing a beige and cream Bonnie Cashin reversible coat and matching dress.  The dress and coat both have leather detailing.  She is photographed in New York's Pan American building.The other clipping is an article with three sketches.  The sketches depict a white "shirt coat" with brown-flecking, a green jersey shirt with matching pants with zippers, and a suede coat with fringe.  These designs are all for Bonnie Cashin's Spring collection for Philip Sills.  This clipping is from the New York Post, the November 2, 1965 edition.  The other clipping may be from the same edition or another source.

Title: Page 7a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin designs it|~|The Bonnie new cashmeres|~|Guess who!
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from New York Herald Tribune, March 7, 1965.  This clipping has two photographs, one in cashmere striped dress, and the other in a turtleneck cashmere sweater.  There are also several sketches of cashmere sweaters and dresses.  The second clipping is an advertisement for Cashin's designs at Wallachs.  Handwritten in the bottom right corner is 1965.  There is a drawing of a woman in a leather coat with a pile-lined hood for added warmth.  It is available in geranium or green tea and costs $135.  The third clipping has two drawings of women in Cashin designs at Liberty in London.  The women wear a hooded jersey dress, a suede coat, a canvas jacket, and trousers.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|skirts (garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|dresses (garments)--1960-1970|~|mohair|~|fringe|~|trousers|~|coats (garments)|~|suede
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 7b
AltTitle.other: Big city look|~|Heap good clothes, thanks to Indian|~|Designer just can't bear bareness: styles show it|~|In the country clothes shop
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first is from the Sunday News Coloroto Magazine, August 8, 1965.  There is a color photo of a woman in a wonderfully bulky, suede-trimmed and suede-sashed jacket with a matchign mohair rope tweed skirt set on a long-waisted dress with jersey bodice.  The dress (which is hidden under the jacket) has a scooped neck and three-quarter sleeves.  The second clipping is from May 7, 1965, source unknown.  There is a photograph of a model in a Cashin fashion show, exhibiting the layer theory of adding or peeling clothes according to the temperatures.  The model in the photograph sheds a ropy mohair jacket and skirt to reveal a hooded jersey dress and high boots.  The article discusses Cashin's layer theory.  The third clipping is an advertisement for Cashin's clothes at Lord & Taylor.  There is a drawing of a woman in a gem of a shortcoat with all the great Bonnie Cashin signatures: flip hood and cuffs, leather piping, and brass closings.  The coat is made of tan cotton canvas and lined with acrylic pile and costs $75.  The fourth clipping has handwritten in the top right corner "World Telegram Feb. 1965".  There is an article discussing Cashin's inspiration from traditional Native American costumes.  There are three sketches of fringed outfits.  They show a shirty dress with fringe tiers; swingy, fringy pants with a fringed overblouse; and a fringed overblouse and a suede dress.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: skirts (garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|purses (ladies' accessories)|~|coats (garments)--1960-1970|~|fringe|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|leather|~|trousers|~|shirts|~|headcloths (headgear)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 8a
AltTitle.other: But, of course... it's Cashin|~|Bonnie Cashin: consistently new|~|American designs for cashmere
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from the New York Journal - American, January 7, 1965.  There is a photograph of Cashin, 5 sketches of Cashin's designs, and 2 photographs of women in Cashin's fashions.  The sketches show: fringed pants; a blouson top in wheat suede; a swingy fringed skirt and classic shirt of wheat suede with hot pink silk lining ($160); a mobile hooded coat in gray flannel with black leather trim ($185); and a variety of Cashin Carry bags from Coach Leatherware.  The photographs show two women in capes, hats, skirts, and leather pants.  The article discusses Cashin's innovations.  The second clipping has handwritten "Apr. /65".  There is a photograph of a woman in a headwrap and a coat.  There is a short article Cashin's sportswear and leatherwear.
