Title: Page 32b
AltTitle.other: Fashion pure and simple|~|Bonnie Cashin in retrospect|~|Signing their fashion as individuals
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first (Vogue, January 1967) has two photographs.  One photograph shows a woman in a saffron yellow hooded felt coat bound with suede.  It costs 75 pounds.  THe other photograph shows a malibu kid tabard lined with blonde wool jersey, a white wool sweater, and beige stretch nylon trousers.  The second clipping (Belfast Telegraph, April 5, 1967) shows a model in a quilted suede skirt, kidskin jacket, and jersey blouse.  The brief article describes cashin's some of design philosophy.  The third clipping (The Maker-up, Vol.56, No.1, January 1967) discusses a Bonnie Cashin retrospective at the Time-Life Building.  There is also a photograph of Bonnie Cashin.

Description.note: One clipping.  An advertisement for Lord & Taylor for coats and dresses by Bonnie Cashin, "designer to the countrywoman-at-large."  The advertisement consists of drawings of women in tweed or leather Bonnie Cashin coats.  There are also smaller sketches of women in Bonnie Cashin dresses.  The coats range in price from $160 to $190.  The dresses are $65.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 9b
AltTitle.other: Beauty in hand by Bonnie Cashin|~|The Country Clothes Shop sports great designer looks for every facet of your life
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (Chicago Tribune, Sept., 1972) is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin's gloves at Marshall Field & Company.  The gloves cost $12 to $20.  The second clipping (Times, Feb. 28, 1972) is an advertisement for The Country Clothes Shop.  The ad features a drawing of a woman in a Cashin coat.  The coat costs $170.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 10a
AltTitle.other: The new freedom
Description.note: One clipping.  From (handwritten above the photograph:) "San Francisco Chronicle June 25/72".  There is a brief caption discussing Fall's newest coats and their wide, roomy, comfortable shapes.  There is a photograph of a roomy tent of a Cashin coat in orange poplin trimmed with bone leather.  The woman also wears a hat and carries a purse.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: capes (outerwear)|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 10b
AltTitle.other: Big shows: roomy wraps: cape combos
Description.note: One Clipping.  From Harper's Bazaar, Sept. 1972.  This clipping features a photograph of a woman in front of a "Cabaret" poster in a Coty Hall of Fame designer Bonnie Cashin cape.  The cape is black and rust double-faced and costs about $250.  The woman is also wearing a hat.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Name.subject: Harper's Bazaar (magazine)
Title: Page 11a
AltTitle.other: Après sportif chic.  Layered suede.  Yellow raccoon.
Description.note: One clipping.  On bottom of page is handwritten "Harper's Bazaar Nov. /72".  There is a photograph of a woman in a total layered look of suede by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills.  The woman wears a long wrap, nut-brown coat lined in Borg pile.  She also wears beige suede knickers, and a hooded suede blouson jacket.  The coat costs abou $275.  Cashin's name is underlined in pen.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: fur|~|greatcoats|~|skullcaps (caps)|~|suede|~|slacks
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 11b
Description.note: One clipping.  Color photograph of a man in a plaid coat and a plaid jacket.  He also wears boots.  A woman wears a tan suede (or leather?) greatcoat with a gray fur lining.  She also wears slacks and skullcap.  A white horse stands with them.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 12a
Description.note: One clipping, handwritten below is "Harper's + Queen Dec. /72 London".  There is a photograph of a man in a single-breasted Prince of Wales check coat and matching hat by Burberry.  There is text mentioning a tan-colored plush cowskin coat with collar and lining in grey Acrilan by Bonnie Cashin, but the clipping does not include a photograph of the ensemble.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 13a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin, fashion innovator; Bonnie Cashin, Coty Hall of Fame; Bonnie Cashin, another Lord & Taylor "find"
Description.note: One clipping.  From The New York Times, September 10, 1972.  An advertisement for Bonnie Cashin at Lord & Taylor.  The coat shown in the sketch costs $350.  The coat has fur around the collar.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|jackets (garments)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|mohair|~|shoulder bags|~|suede
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 13b
AltTitle.other: The unique Bonnie Cashin|~|Bonnie Cashin presented Coty 'Hall of Fame' award|~|This newest version
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first has handwritten in red "Friday - Oct. 20 - 72" and in black "Pasadena Star New".  The accompanying article, which notes the fact that Cashin has an aunt in Pasadena, discusses Cashin's recent Hall of Fame Coty Award.  There is a photograph of a woman in a beige mohair blend kimono wrap coat with buck suede trim.  The woman also wears a headcloth.  The second clipping has "Bonwit Teller" handwritten on the bottom.  This clipping is an advertisement for Cashin handbags.  There is drawing of a woman in a turtleneck sweater, carrying Cashin's soft-shoulder glove-tanned cowhide purse with a holster closing.  The bag comes in putty, bone, red, navy or black and costs $36.  The third clipping has handwritten "LA. Times 8/14/72" in pen and is an advertisement for Cashin at Saks Fifth Avenue in Beverly Hills.  There is a drawing of a kimono-cut Noh shape coat in leather with a fur collar.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: coatdresses|~|capes (outerwear)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|stolas|~|layering
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 14a
AltTitle.other: Cashin's spring is an anytime thing|~|All winners in this shell game
Description.note: Two clippings.  The firs clipping (Daily News, Mar. 28, 1972) discusses Cashin's originality, with particular emphasis on her love of layers.  There is an accompanying photograph of a model in a coatdress.  She also wears a hood and a stola-like shell.  The second clipping (Daily News, Jan. 29, 1972) discusses how Cashin does not believe clothes should be seasonal, yet instead environmental.  There is an image of a model in a dress, cape, and hood.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 14b
AltTitle.other: Nothing ho-hum about Cashin show
Description.note: One clipping.  Source and date unknown.  From a column by Sally Raleigh.  In pencil above title is handwritten "Cashin".  Cashin's name is also underlined in red in the first sentence.  The article discusses Cashin's designs at the American Designer Showings for Spring.  Cashin did her own commentary for her show.  Cashin also discussed piracy in the fashion world.  The article mentions Cashin's caftans, leather trim, and her fun, made to wear designs.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: jackets (garments)|~|vests (garments)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|stripes|~|leather|~|trousers|~|greatcoats|~|suede
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 15
AltTitle.other: Cashin designs the uncluttered garments|~|Everything great a coat can be in a Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from the Daily Hampshire Gazette, Northampton, Mass., December 9, 1972.  The article discusses the uncluttered nature of Cashin's designs.  There are two photographs.  One shows a front tied sleeveless suede jacket (a vest?) and pants of wool jersey by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills' Resort and Spring 1973 collection.  The other photograph shows a cotton jacket in beige with a carry-all in back, as well as kidskin pants from Bonnie Cashin's Resort and Spring 1973 collection for Philip Sills.  The second clipping is an advertisement for Cashin's coats at Kramer's in Carmel-by-the-Sea, California.  Handwritten in pencil below is "9/22/72- Manita" (?).

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|trousers
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 16a
AltTitle.other: Potpourri|~|Trigere and Cashin score: two hits, no errors
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (News American Dec. 4, 1972) is an article praising Bonnie Cashin and her pioneering use of leather and suede.  The second (Daily News, Nov. 4, 1972) has an article discussing the Spring collections of Pauline Trigere and Bonnie Cashin.  There is a photograph of a woman in Cashin sling pants in suede held up by ribbon-thin ties.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|suits (main garments)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|sweaters--1970-1980|~|trousers|~|fur|~|greatcoats|~|gloves|~|suede|~|plaids|~|maxiskirts|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 16b
AltTitle.other: Mary Chapin has beautiful clothes for active people...
Description.abstract: Two clippings.  The first is shows two women in Bonnie Cashin fashions.  These two photographs are from Gossip, September 9 (year unknown).  One woman wears a suede coat with a big fur cape-like collar.  The second woman wears a mohair and wool suit, plaided in deep, rich, subtle color tones.  The second clipping is from Gossip, September 5 (year unknown).  This clipping discusses Cashin's fall collection available at Mary Chapin

Title: Page 17a
AltTitle.other: Country Cashin
Description.note: One clipping.  A photograph of a woman in a greatcoat with a fur lining pulled up over half her face.  She also wears a hood and pants.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 17b
AltTitle.other: Happiness is...a new Fall wardrobe
Description.note: One clipping.  From Gossip Toronto, Sept. 1972.  Clipping shows a photograph of a woman in a Cashin suit and skullcap.  The jacket flares out like a basquine.  The text reads "Happiness is..." above the model and "...a new Fall Wardrobe" below.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: jackets (garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|hoods (headgear)|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|tweed|~|fringe|~|trousers|~|frogs (fasteners)|~|suede|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 18b
AltTitle.other: Bright fashions go many places
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (The Oregonian, February 21, 1972) notes a trunk showing of Bonnie Cashin's collection and features three photographs of her brightly colored designs: a fringed tweed suit jacket, a "rice picker" outfit, and a long jersey dress with a matching suede cape.  The second clipping (The Plain Dealer, December 1, 1972) has a handwritten note above the paper's name: "Cleveland-- Anne Anable".  There is a brief article about Cashin's designs.  There is also a photograph of a woman in Cashin's suede sling pants, and a hooded top.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 19a
AltTitle.other: Fall designer preview: Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: One clipping.  Advertisement for Cashin's designs at Halle's.  There is a drawing of a woman in a soft necked jersey maxi dress and nubbed coat in plum or red.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: jackets (garments)|~|shorts (garments)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|trousers
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 19b
AltTitle.other: And the offbeat goes on, this fall|~|Around the town with Mary Walpole
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (Daily News, May 5, 1972) discusses Bonnie Cashin and also designer Rudi Gernreich.  There is a discussion of Cashin's fashions, including her biking clothes for "anti-pollutant activists who prefer bikes to cars."  There is also a photograph which shows Cashin's biking shorts and up-curving jacket which allows for a bike seat.  There is also another woman in a Cashin hood, jacket, and pants.  The second clipping ("Toronto-Canada" written at the top) is a brief article advertising for Bonnie Cashin clothes at the Mary Chapin store.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|scarves (costume accessories)|~|jackets (garments)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|trousers|~|plaids
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 20a
AltTitle.other: Today's woman - Fall 1972 the Fashion Group, inc. of Chicago American Designer Show|~|Spring is somewhere...
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from the New York Post, November 7, 1972.  The article (which is bracketed in red pen) discusses the timeless and functional nature of Cashin's designs.  It is also noted that Cashin avoids producing boring designs thanks to her eye for texture and pattern.  There is a photograph of a woman in a headcloth/hood, a plaid jacket with a cowl neck (or scarf?), and pants.  There is also a photograph of a woman in a bubble jacket, headcloth/hood, and pants.  The second clipping is text on a mustard colored background.  Cashin's name is underlined in red pen.  The clipping discusses the American Designer show and there is a quote from Cashin about marvelous looking people.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 20b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin Coty hall of fame, 1972
Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten on the side in pencil "147%" (?).  The clipping has a photograph of Cashin's face.  The clipping discusses Cashin's background and design philosophy.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|fur|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 21a
AltTitle.other: Glenoit makes you feel good.
Description.note: One Clipping.  An advertisement for "Sills/A Bonnie Cashin Design" coat in pile fabric by Glenoit.  Photograph of a woman and a man in coats and hats.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: jackets (garments)|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|leather|~|trousers|~|suede|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 21b
AltTitle.other: Cashin chides designers, goes them one better
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from "Amy Vanderbilt's Newsletter: An exclusive Service of The Army Vanderbilt Success Program for Women".  This clipping discusses Cashin's classic and colorful designs.  The second clipping is from the Dayton Daily News, December 1, 1972.  This article discusses Cashin's disgust with the copying that goes on in the fashion industry.  There are two accompanying photographs.  One shows a woman in a bamboo-pink mohair jacket and buck-colored suede pants.  She also carries a messenger bag (purse?).  The second photograph shows a jacket with a built in carry-all backpack.  The jacket is beige cotton and the pants are made of kidskin.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 22
AltTitle.other: Suede escapade
Description.note: One clipping.  Source and date unknown.  There is a photograph of a man and a woman in a variety of suede pieces.  There is an "x" written on the woman's jacket in pen and the "Crescendoe-Superb gloves" are underlined.

There is a photograph of a woman in a buck-suede cape, headcloth, and suede sleeveless dress with snap fasteners in front.

Title: Page 24a
AltTitle.other: Cashin collection startling after parade of pastels
Description.note: One clipping.  From The Evening Times, Trenton, N.J., December 1, 1972.  Article discussing Cashin's originality in her designs.  Also features a photograph of a woman in a hat, a crop top/choli, and a skirt with pockets and an uneven hem.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 24b
AltTitle.other: No fads in her designs
Description.note: One clipping.  From the New Haven Journal-Courier, January 31, 1972.  There is a photograph of Bonnie Cashin in a striped hooded sweater, and a jacket.  There is also a photograph of a woman in a canvas jacket with a great leather totable bag secured to the back of the jacket with self-bandings.  The same leather flatters the collar.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: jackets (garments)|~|cardigans|~|capes (outerwear)|~|hoods (headgear)|~|tweed|~|fur|~|gloves|~|suede|~|maxiskirts|~|hats|~|cocktail dresses
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 25a
AltTitle.other: It's Hall of Fame for Cashin: here's why
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Boston Herald Traveler, August 18, 1972.  Article discussing Cashin's third Coty American Fashion Critics' Award and subsequent placement in the Fashion Hall of Fame.  The article notes that the Committee find Cashin's most recent Fall collection her strongest yet.  Four photographs accompany the article.  The first shows a woman in an indigo suede bicycle jacket and blue jean jersey pants.  The second shows a woman in a printed wool cardigan and side-slit maxi-skirt.  The third shows a woman in a grey loden cape trimmed with black leather.  The fourth shows a woman in a red wool jersey evening dress.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: jackets (garments)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|trousers|~|suede|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 25b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin's noh play
Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten above article is "N.Y. Post May 5/72".  The article is from Ruth Preston's column Talk About Clothes.  The article discusses the color palette of Cashin's latest collection, and how the colors work so well with Cashin's layered looks.  There is a photograph of a woman in an un-cut-up Noh silhouette wrap, in suede.  The woman also wears jersey pants.  There is also a photograph of a woman in a sparrow gray suede dress and a melon turtleneck sweater underneath the dress.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|capes (outerwear)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|plaids
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 26a
Description.note: One clipping, from The New York Times Magazine, September 24, 1972.  There is a photograph of a great coverup in a thick wool plaid from Scotland in uncommon colors (purple, dill green). It underscores the Cashin passion for mantles and ponchos. “I just love anything uncutup. I respect beautiful textures and hate to torture them.” For Philip Sills. $325 at Saks Fifth. The wrapped head is another Cashin trademark.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|leather|~|fur|~|gloves
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 26b
AltTitle.other: Tuning in to Bonnie's wavelength
Description.note: One clipping.  From N.Y. Times, Aug. 27, 1972.  An advertisement for the Bonnie Cashin collection at Saks Fifth Avenue.  Clipping features a sketch of a woman in a hood and floor length coat.  The coat is $310.  There is also a sketch of tan and beige Cashin gloves in handsewn, washable pigskin ($24).

AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin only at Liberty's
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is a photograph of a woman walking.  She wears a patterned matching jacket and skirt, with a daisy flower pin.  She also wears a checkered hat and has a leather shoulder bag.  Handwritten below the clipping is "Vogue" and on the photograph there is handwritten with an arrow pointing at the skirt "April 15 1972".  The second clipping is an advertisement for Cashin at Liberty's.  There is a drawing of a woman in a leather racoon trimmed coat in goldfinch, peat, and black.  It costs £195.  There is also a hooded cashmere sweater that costs £16.80.  This sentenced is underlined twice and written below is "$43.68".

Title: Page 31a
AltTitle.other: A great find, but that's your usual style.
Description.note: One clipping.  From (underlined on bottom right corner of page) Vogue, September 15, 1972.  Four photographs of a woman in the same outfit.  She wears a hood, pants, and a Bonnie Cashin wraparound jacket in supple turf tan leather with a luxurious smoky beige long-haired Borg fabric of pure modacrylic lining.  It costs $275.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 31b
AltTitle.other: Cyclin' with Cashin|~|For Bonnie Cashin, it's a time to shine
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first clipping is from the Washington Star, February 13, 1972.  Handwritten on the top of the first clipping is "Wash. Star Feb 13/72".  This clipping shows a photograph of a woman climbing onto a bicycle.  The woman wears a free-wheeling canvas jacket designed by Cashin for Philip Sills with the leather totable bag secured to the back of the jacket with self-bandings and worn with cycle knickers.  The Cashin designs are available at Saks Fifth Avenue.  The second clipping is from the New York Times, May 5, 1972.  Handwritten on the top of the clipping is "N.Y. Times Fri. May 5/72".  This clipping shows a woman in a wrap jacket and matching pants by Cashin for Sills.  The woman also wears a turtleneck sweater.  The accompanying article discusses Cashin's use of experimental shapes and colors in her designs.

Title: Page 32a
AltTitle.other: The Cashin glove|~|Fall designer preview: Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: Two clippings.  Both advertisements for Cashin at Halle's.  The first shows a drawing of a woman in a long wool nubbed coat ribbed in suede (in plum or red), and a soft necked jersey dress.  The second clipping has a drawing of a Cashin glove in creamy smooth leather.  It comes in white, black, or dove and costs $16.

Title: Page 32b
AltTitle.other: Cashin: voice of American design
Description.note: One clipping, handwritten above "Wash. Star - Feb. 16/72".  There is a photograph of a woman in a gold canvas coat with a loaf of bread and jug of wine.  The article discusses Cashin's groundbreaking fashion designs.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 33a
AltTitle.other: Dramatic design: Bonnie Cashin focuses function on sporty, countryish good looks|~|London shop big seller of Cashin-- to tourists
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first has handwritten at the top of the clipping "C.S. Monitor Mar. 24 '72".  This clipping has a photograph of a tie-belted empire coat in soft glove white leather that can be worn with the belt tied loosely at back or wrapped in the front.  The accompanying article discusses the relationship between form and function in Cashin's designs.  The second clipping is from Women's Wear Daily, November 15, 1972.  This article discusses the amount of business Libery of London's Cashin's store gets from American tourists.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 33b
AltTitle.other: Fashion B.C.
Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten below article: "British Harpers Bazaar + Queen."  Article discusses Cashin's designs.  There is also discussion of her design philosophy and what's next for Cashin.  There are two photographs accompanying the article.  They show actress Sian Phillips wearing Cashin's designs.  She is pictured in one photo in: a dark beige suede trouser suit; a smock-shaped jacket, gathered from yoke at back, with dropped shoulder seams, side patch pockets, and gilt clip fastenings; and matching wide trousers.  In the other picture she wears: a long grey wool cape piped in black leather, with leather collar, and deep pockets; and a long slim-fitting wool jersey dress, piped in black leather, with gilt buttons down front.

AltTitle.other: Like money in the bank: Bonnie Cashin plans for an expansive future
Description.note: One clipping. An advertisement for Saks Fifth Avenue. There is a brief article discussing Cashin's seasonless designs. There is a photograph of two women in Cashin's designs. They both wear capes, with dresses with hoods beneath.

Title: Page 2b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin knows.  One great sport bag carries the day.|~|Bundled|~|Pure Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is an advertisement for Cashin's bags.  Handwritten in the bottom left is "SF Chronicle 8/14/75".  There are drawings of four purses.  They are: a tote with a sports-car side pocket ($64), a bucket bag ($65), a roll bag ($55), and a body-hugger ($48).  The second clipping is Bonnie Cashin at Lord & Taylor.  There is a drawing of a short but cozy canvas jacket with acrylic pile lining, leather piping and collar.  On the bottom of the advertisement is handwritten "N.Y. Times Spet. 23/75".  The third clipping is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin for Evelyn Pearson at B. Altman & Co.  There is a drawing of a woman in a belted robe, with a long line of acrylic fleece, trim of acetate satin, and comes in pink or blue.  It costs $43.  Next to the drawing in pen is handwritten "N.Y. Times Dec. /75" and below is handwritten "Times".

Title: Page 3a
AltTitle.other: Spectrum|~|Lipmans
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from Milwaukee Journal Spectrum, June 15, 1975.  This clipping shows a photograph of a woman in a room filled with plants.  She wears a brown coat with two buttons on top.  The rest of the coat is cutaway so that her brown shirt and skirt are visible.  She wears a hat too.  The second clipping is an advertisement for Lipmans in Portland, Oregon.  On the bottom right side of the clipping is handwritten "PORTLAND, ORE."  There is a drawing of a woman in a jacket, turtleneck sweater, and hat.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 3b
AltTitle.other: The brass hopper|~|Organized amplitude: that's Bonnie Cashin's new attitude towards handbags for the many lives you lead.|~|An elaborate yarn
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from The Washington Post, August 7, 1975.  Advertisement for Bonnie Cashin's bags and purses at Saks Fifth Avenue.  There is a drawing of two bags.  One has a fold-over framed outside purse, with a detachable shoulder strap that turns the bag into a clutch ($47).  There is also a bucket bag with a top zip closing and an outside framed purse ($56).  The second clipping has handwritten on the top of the clipping "Bonwit Teller - Aug. 7/75."  There is a drawing of a bag and a  coat.  The coat has deep contrast ribbing, drawstring hood, and richly punctuated pockets.  The bag is a hybrid bag that can be either a clutch or a shoulder bag.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|skirts (garments)|~|ponchos|~|pullovers|~|hoods (headgear)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|stripes|~|ombré|~|trousers|~|dirndls
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 4a
AltTitle.other: Layering-- a "Bonnie" idea catches fashion's fancy
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Chicago Tribune, August 14, 1975.  Article discussing Cashin's work with layering.  Three color photographs accompany the article.  The first photograph shows a cape-sleeved wool knit rust colored coat for Philip Sills piped in leather, and lined in striped jersey; and also a poncho of Shetland wool for the Knittery with a rib-knit collar.  The second photograph shows a tricolor ombred pullover of brushed Shetland with pants and a hooded sweater; and a dirndl skirt on top of a stipred dress.  The third photograph shows a hooded striped jersey dress, belted and piped in leather; and also a lamb's wool sweater with a funnel collar that forms a hood and matching pants.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|suits (main garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|bathrobes|~|vests (garments)|~|trousers|~|fur|~|jump suits|~|burnouses|~|chiffon|~|headcloths (headgear)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 4b
AltTitle.other: New designs for private lives|~|Faced with restrictions, furriers show they can be creative|~|Pearson launches first line of Bonnie Cashin loungewear
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from Body Fashions/Intimate Apparel July 1975.  The article Cashin's collection for Evelyn Pearson which includes three basic groupings: Creature Comforts for private times, Active Home Gear or warm-ups, and Special Hours At-Home.  There is a photograph of Bonnie Cashin, as well as one of Evelyn Pearson.  There are also photographs of an all-cotton stretch terry burnoose (pale aqua or soft pink, $56), a furry wide-wale Acrilan acrylic kimono with bandaged waistline (Killarny green, Wisteria, or Dutch blue, $47), and a printed double-layered nylon chiffon Noh robe (muted gold tones, $68).  The second clipping has handwritten above "Playbill - Oct. '75."  There is a drawing of a three women in designs by John Kloss, Bonnie Cashin, and Halston.  The section about Cashin is bracketed in red.  The drawing shows a long sleeved, oak colored jersey jumpsuit with gold chain-link buttons topped by a furry shell with wedge shaped pockets.  Both the shell and the jacket are $75.  The third clipping is about restrictions placed on furriers by conservationists, and how furriers are dealing with the restrictions.  There is a photograph of Cashin's lamb pants suit ($2,500).

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 5a
AltTitle.other: Organized amplitude: that's Bonnie Cashin's new attitude towards handbags for the many lives you lead.
Description.note: 1 clipping.  From N.Y. Times November 1975.  Brief article describing Cashin's versatile handbags with a framed section.  Drawing of four purses, including one in action to better describe how the purse functions.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: bathrobes|~|stripes|~|caftans
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 5b
AltTitle.other: Medieval splendor|~|White Christmas|~|Bonnie Cashin for Evelyn Pearson|~|Middle Eastern styling for the Western woman
Description.note: Four clippings, all of Bonnie Cashin for Evelyn Pearson designs.  The first is a color drawing (watercolor?) of a woman in a purple, green, and pink striped caftan.  There are buttons at the top of the caftan.  It is made of Arnel triacetate and nylon.  On the right side is written "Lord + Taylor Xmas 1975."  The second clipping is a photograph of a woman in the same caftan.  In pen on the bottom of the page it says "Macy's Xmas '75."  The third clipping is a photograph of a woman in a luxurious white acrylic pile with stitched and scalloped trim.  On the bottom left of the clipping it reads in red "Nieman Marcus Xmas 1975."  The fourth clipping is a photograph of a woman in a monk robe in cotton velour, the color of a fine, mellow brandy.  It has a sweater knit neckline and side slits.  Above the caption in pen is written "I. Magnin - '75."

Title: Page 6a
AltTitle.other: Your evenings at home.
Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten above clipping it says "Harpers Bazaar- 1975."  The clipping shows a photograph of a woman in a black and white striped kimono for around the house.  It is by Bonnie Cashin for Evelyn Pearson.  It is polyester and costs about $60.

AltTitle.other: Be beautifully at-ease at home.|~|"Geoffrey, you have to go home some time..."
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from Cosmopolitan (Cosmo).  There is a photograph of a woman in a vamp robe of Arneland nylon fleece in black and soft pink.  It is Bonnie Cashin for Evelyn Pearson, costs $49, and is being admired by a man in the photograph.  On the Cosmo masthead is written "Nov. /75".  The second clipping shows a photograph of a woman in a purple, pink, and green caftan of Arnel triacetate and nylone.  It costs $55.  Above the picture is written "Garfinkels - Xmas 1975."

AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin creates the ultimate in loungers for Evelyn Pearson
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Chicago Tribune, October 6, 1975.  The clipping is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin loungers for Evelyn Pearson.  There is a photograph of a striped fleece burnoose of Arnel triacetate and nylon in purple, green, and pink combination ($55).  There is also a baby bunting robe of acrylic in pink or lime ($43).  The text also notes that Cashin will personally introduce her loungewear collection at a Marshall Field & Company location.

Article by Anne-Marie Schiro about the exhibition.  There are various pictures of bags featured in the exhibition surrounding the article.  Included is a photograph of a leather body bag by Bonnie Cashin for Meyers.

Title: Page 9a
AltTitle.other: Looking fantastic from forty on: Princess Grace of Monaco|~|The swing of a cape
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from Harper's Bazaar, August 1975.  There is a photograph of Princess Grace of Monaco is a full swinging cape of pitch-brown tweed piped with suede, and a soft slouch hat.  The mohair cape is by Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills.  The second clipping is close up photograph of a woman (also Princess Grace?).  She wears a hood and a knit sweater.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|scarves (costume accessories)|~|jackets (garments)|~|ponchos|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|fur|~|dirndls|~|skullcaps (caps)|~|plaids
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 9b
AltTitle.other: Virginia is passing on her sense of style to her children|~|The contemporary Cashin, celebrating the American way with clothes|~|Furs for you to enjoy|~|Big scarf is suit collar
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first (handwritten below: "Dec./75") is an advertisement for Gene Burton.  There is a drawing of a woman in a Bonnie Cashin Canadian natural lynx poncho ($1700).  The second clipping (The New York Times Magazine, August 24, 1975) discusses one woman (Virginia)'s sense of style.  She is photographed, with her children, in a Cashin wool suit with a jacket that wraps to the back.  The collar of the jacket is actually a scarf.  The suit has a dirndl skirt.  The third clipping (handwritten: "Detroit News Aug./75") shows the same suit as the second clipping.  The text notes that the Pilgrim shawl collar suit is a tweedy brown wool plaid piped in suede.  The model also wears a hand-knit "Priscilla cap."  The fourth clipping (handwritten: "Boston Sunday Globe- Sept. 7/75") is an advertisement for Saks Fifth Avenue.  It shows a drawing of a woman in long Cashin coat and a shawl.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: turtleneck sweaters|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|robes (main garments)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 10a
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first shows a Bonnie Cashin for Evelyn Pearson robe in furry polyester in a palette of colors including mauve, black, shocking, light pink, white, or mocha.  There is a drawing of the robe.  The second clipping has some brief text on Shelley Pfeifer, fashion coordinator and stylist.  She is shown in a Cashin beige cashmere funnelneck sweater dress.  The fourth clipping (handwritten: "Aug 6/75") has a sketch of a woman with a bag.  This bag can be a shoulder bag one day and a wrist bag another day.  The bag is for Coach.  Cashin is not mentioned, but the Coach design is possibly her's.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 10b
AltTitle.other: Focus: Fall|~|Leather at hand: Bonnie Cashin for Meyers
Description.note: One clipping, from The Plain Dealer, August 12, 1975.  Two brief articles.  The first advertises the Bonnie Cashin for Sills collection, which can be found at Halle's Downtown.  There is also a photograph of a woman in a most dramatic cape-sleeved coat, brushed charcoal wool banded in caramel leather.  Underneath, there is a leather-piped hooded "T" of a dress in charcoal acrylic and wool jersey.  However, the dress is not apparent in the photograph.  The second brief article advertises the Bonnie Cashin for Meyers leather bags.  They come in a variety of colors such as rum, plum, pewter, and peanut butter.

Title: Page 11a
Description.note: 1 clipping.  From the Chicago Tribune, February 19, 1975.  Advertisement for The Country Shop at Marshall Field & Company.  Three Cashin outfits are shown: a houndstooth (or oakwood tweed) wool very loose-fitting coat with leather trim, a matching skirt, and a oak acrylic and wool hooded top with suede trim; a white acrylic and wool dress trimmed with leather with a tie belt at the waist; and a houndstooth (or oakwood tweed) square jacket with suede trim, a acrylic and wool turtleneck, and oak suede pants.

Title: Page 11b
AltTitle.other: At-homes clothes should stay at home.|~|When it's cold, this works fast|~|Bonnie loungewear
Description.note: Three clippings, all black and white.  The first is an article from September 29, 1975 (source unknown).  The article discusses Cashin's at-home clothes.  It discusses her desgins, and the various times at home that one might wear them.  There are four images.  The first shows a big snap-sided colorful terry cloth poncho ($43).  The second shows a two piece fleece-backed, cotton-knit jogging suit with contrasting topstitching ($52).  The third shows a lilac cotton dress faced with shocking pink ($55) and detailed with a quilted apron front of moss green with an attached matching pot-holder.  The fourth shows a cozy robe in baby bunting fleece, sashed and bordered in satin, similar to a blanket ($43).The second clipping has handwritten "W.W. Jan 9/75" on it (Women's Wear?) and the article is circled in red.  This brief article discusses Cashin's loungewear collection.The third clipping has a photograph of a woman in a long, cozy mustard-color velour "sweatshirt" to sleep in, with a knit turtleneck collar and cuffs ($63).  There is an accompanying caption.

AltTitle.other: Cuddle up in comfort|~|Touch of leather
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first (The Sacramento Bee, February 13, 1975) discusses Cashin's use of leather in her designs.  There are three accompanying photographs.  They show: a red and neutral bamboo jersey coat (and a handbag), a leather skirt suit, and a "squarish" loose-fitting three-quarter sleeve jacket in houndstooth.  The second clipping (handwritten: Wash. DC. Star Nov. 18/75") discusses the comfort inherent in Cashin's designs.  In particular, the article focusese on Cashin's latest robes.  Pictured are two of these robes.

Title: Page 20a
AltTitle.other: Informal modeling Thursday downtown from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Seattle Times, February 11, 1976.  Handwritten at top of clipping is "Seattle Times Feb. 11/76".  This clipping is an advertisement for Cashin fashions at Frederick & Nelson: A Division of Marshall Field & Company.  The ad notes that there will be informal modeling of Cashin's designs at the store with Mr. Arthur Sheer, Cashin's representative.  There are three sketches shown in the clipping.  Shown are: a white cotton canvas suit (skirt, jacket) with leather yoke and trim ($250); a double-faced featherweight wool cape with leather yoke, beige lined with white ($260); and a white cotton canvas coat with sandstone leather ($220).  Cashin's collection ranges from $198 to $380.

Title: Page 20b
AltTitle.other: Knits that are forever|~|'People change' keys Cashin line for '76
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first has handwritten on the left hand side "Oregon Journal - Feb. 8 - 1976".  The "8" is somewhat illegible.  This clipping has a photograph of a woman in a suede coat designed for Sills & Co. by Cashin.  The coat is unstructured without lining.  The coat is designed inside and outside with each seam contributing to the all-over graphic design.  The second clipping has handwritten above "NY Times".  It is from May 11, 1976.  This clipping has a photograph of a woman in "Amelia" bloomers by Cashin, a turtleneck shirt (sweater?) and a belt (?).  The accompanying article discusses Cashin's predilection for paprika, a strong orange-red color, as well as her passion for bloomers.  The third clipping is from the Chicago Sun-Times, May 10, 1971.  This clipping has two sketches accompanying a brief article about Cashin's most recent collection.  One sketch shows a hooded black poplin coat traced in leather and lined with a pile fabric.  Cashin's sketch points out the details of the coat.  The second sketch shows an unlined purple cowhide coat.  The fourth clipping has handwritten above the clipping "NY Times July 1976".  This clipping shows a sketch of a woman in a hooded maxidress and a poncho.  The accompanying article discusses Cashin's Knittery.

She also holds up a strped scarf (or shirt?).  The second clipping is a photograph of a mannequin in a track suit with zippered pockets.  She also holds a purse. AltTitle.other: Body - container|~|Tomorrow begins today|~|The future begins
Description.note: Four clippings.  The first says "the future begins" at the top of the clipping.  It is unclear if the title is covered by the clipping next to it or not.  Below is written "International Design Conference in Aspen/" and the rest is covered by other clippings.  The second clipping is a handwritten note / letter by Cashin about her "body - container" design and Cashin's other futuristic designs.  The third clipping is a sketch of Cashin's body - container design.  This sketch shows the details of Cashin's design including: a zip stoway pocket for $100 bills; big white eye shades; double cotton leather traced on the poncho; big zips; drawstring; sheer tights -- plain color; and a big Cashin Carry purse.  The fourth clipping shows a woman actually wearing Cashin's body - container.  Cashin is also in the photograph wearing a headwrap, a sweater, and pants.

AltTitle.other: Profiles of quality|~|Give me me liberty-y
Description.note: Two clippings. One clipping is layered on top of the other. The bottom clipping shows part of the cover for American Fabrics and Fashions. Connected to cover are two short passages, at least one by the editors of American Fabrics and Fashions.  These passages discuss quality in clothing.  Bonnie Cashin is mentioned.  The second passage notes that the Cashin homage begins on p. 33.  The second clipping is a page homage to Cashin.  There is a sketch by Cashin of a woman wearing a barrel with the text "Give me me liberty-y."  There is also a smaller sketch of a woman in a hat, shawl and coat, with Cashin's signature.  The issue of American Fabrics and Fashions is No. 106 from Winter 1976.

This clipping has many quotations by Cashin about her work and the joy she derives from it.  There are two sketches and one photograph in this clipping.  The photograph shows a woman in gloves that flare out at the forearms, a hood (scarf?), and a tweed suit comprised of pants and a matching shawl / scarf. Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 26a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin speaks for herself (continued)
Description.note: "Bonnie Cashin Speaks for herself (continued): I see young people of a half century from now looking absolutely marvelous, because they reflect the great environment in which they will live. Fashion’s role will be as an adjunct to the fully involved life, not a fad, not a relief from boredom or a comic relief. And not just big business. The future look is clean, unencumbered, free and much more individual in the pure sense than fashion is today—almost, you might say, non-fashion. I see color a much greater dimension than it is now, the head-to-toe effect composed, somewhat, as a walking collage. People will be educated to this, and each person will, in a sense, be able to design himself. The young will no longer need to look at the world through a rear-view mirror, dressing as Edwardians or gypsies or biblical characters to make their point. They will be too busy planning ahead. They will look at their bodies with pride, conducting themselves with grace. The “in” four-letter words might be “work” and “give.” And “love,” in the most delightful sense. Everything will be sized small, medium and tall (not large, because obesity will be a sin). Practically all clothing will be laminated, fused, molded or knitted into shape without sewing. Another technique will be a return to simple draping and tieing—a concept still used in some “developing” countries. Cosmetics will play a large role, not so much as facial adornment but as body insulation or chemistry to protect from extreme cold or heat. This, along with actual weather control, will cancel out the need for heavy clothing and furs. Fabrics and substances yet unborn will employ technology to a creative extent that we have not yet seen. There will be more un-cut-up “dressmaking” techniques used, but the word dressmaker may well be almost extinct. The dart, the seam, the hem, the detail fittings will go into the Brooklyn Museum Design Laboratory archives, along with the obsolete government charts of sizes used in our clothing industry today. I think, too, that the “layered” concept, which has long been an involvement of mine, will continue in new applications. For instance, six very thin layers of a new substance, each permeated with certain chemical qualities, molded into identical layered coverings, could be peeled off or donned as the need requires, much like an onion. This is the concept, I think, from which space-travel clothing will evolve, and that evolution should come before 2019."|~|One clipping, from American Fabrics and Fashions, Winter 1976.  Article continued from previous page of "Bonnie Cashin Speaks For Herself."  The article continues discussing Cashin's work with layering.  There are a variety of photographs and a drawing accompanying this section of the article.  The drawing shows a furry Noh perennial jacket, lined with jersey, wind-checked with the sybarite cashmere funnel neck sweater.  The photographs show: a plaid, tweed ankle-length cape with a hood; a canvas-tough, alpaca lined jacket and skirt suit, traced in leather; a striped cashmere turtleneck sweater, a suede shell, and jersey pants; a huge plaid wool cape; a fringed matching shirt and pedal pushers; and a bubble insulation-suede and leather patchwork jacket.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 26b
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin on fashion designing
Description.note: One clipping.  From American Fabrics and Fashions, No. 106, Winter 1976.  The clipping has an essay by Bonnie Cashin about her design inspirations and thoughts about fashion.  There are three images.  The first shows a woman in a turtleneck sweater and a three-quarter sleeve Noh greatcoat in suede lined in raccoon.  There is also a handknit mohair body and hand warmer.  Below that photograph is a sketch of a woman in a coat, knit hat, and pants.  There is a quotation about Cashin's body bag which she notes can be worn under coats and suits to foil purse snatchers.  There is another photograph of a woman in a knit cap, turtleneck, pants, and jacket with an attached purse (?).  Below the article there is also an image of text that reads: "Thank you is a two-in-one word, a two-way-street word, a gift to the giver, thus-- we thank you."

AltTitle.other: Met. day people
Description.note: One clipping.  From American Fabrics and Fashions Winter 1976 (December 1976 - February 1977?).  This clipping seems to be from the same issue of American Fabrics and Fashions as 21198/zz0008bbvw and 21198/zz0008bc1z.  This clipping has a variety of skethces showing "Met. Day people" (?).  The sketches seem to show a variety of costumes.  Many seem to be body suits or cat suits.  Cashin has written notes next to some of the sketches.  One suit seems to have feathers and "birds" is written next to it.  One suit has "grass" written next to it, another has "ducks", and another has "alligator".  One word is illegible (fern?).  The cat suits seem to be depicting specific plants or animals.

The first is a large, deep, soft leather shoulder bag with a pull-over tab that adjusts for closing ($66).  The second is a large soft leather bag with a shoulder strap and tap detailing ($56). Description.note: Four clippings.  The first is a cover from Harper's Bazaar August 1976.  There is a woman on cover in a red-pink cashmere turtleneck sweater.  The second clipping is from the same issue of Harper's Bazaar noting the sources of the image on the cover.  The sweater on the cover is by Cashin.  The third clipping shows a Cashin "body bag" purse that hugs one's side and stays comfortably in place.  The purse is made of soft bone leather with giant zipper inner pocket.  The fourth clipping has a small photograph of Cashin and discusses Cashin's natural affinity for leather.  The fifthe clipping is invitation (?) for the Leather Industries of America American Designer Award 1976 Award Presentation on March 9, 1976.

The second clipping (handwritten: "W.W. Mar. 12/75") is a short article noting that Cashin will now be designing for Meyers Mfg. with a Fall collection in leather and fabric. From the Philip Sills collection: cotton canvas poncho lined in Irish tweed and outlined in leather; a tweed bubble jacket; slim leather pants; double-faced wool jersey jacket (green tea on the outside, red inside); a big wool turtleneck; an unconstructed easy suit in a loopy multi-colored tweed; a funnel sweater; and a knit head wrap. There is also an image of Cashin in a turban, cardigan, and dress, holding a drink.  The second clipping (handwritten: GAP) is a short article in French about Cashin's designs. Description.note: Two clippings.  The first has "F.A. Monday- Jun. 26-'76" written below.  It is an advertisement for Cashin's clothes at Saks Fifth Avenue.  There is a drawing of a woman in a Cashin coat, turtleneck sweater, and skirt.  The second clipping (handwritten: "Times Feb./76") is an advertisement for Cashin clothes at Lord & Taylor.  There is a drawing of a woman in a leather coat that comes in turf or red.  The woman also wears a scarf.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: tote bags|~|purses (ladies' accessories)|~|bags (costume accessories)|~|leather|~|shoulder bags
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 32a
AltTitle.other: The new soft-sell
Description.note: Five clippings.  Sources and dates unknown.  The first shows a Cashin body hug of a bag that looks like it's been poured into shape in the softest, most mellow sand, camel or navy leather.  It costs $61.  There is also a drawing of Craely's carefree cotton knit t-shirt dress.  The second clipping shows a leather tote with a snap mesh (? latticed?) pocket in front.  The third clipping shows a purse with folded over flaps on both sides of the purse.  The fourth shows a purse with a short strap and a fold over flap.  The fifth clippng shows a shoulder sbag of glove-tanned cowhide you can fold either way to hide or reveal the framed purse on the exterior of the bag.  The strap comes off so you can carry the bag as a clutch.  It costs $47.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: cashmere (wool)|~|purses (ladies' accessories)|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|sweaters--1970-1980|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 32b
AltTitle.other: Gene Burton|~|Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: Five clippings, all seem to be from the same source (a Gene Burton catalog?).  The first clipping has a brief article about Bonnie Cashin by Gene Burton.  There is a quotation from Cashin that explains her design philosophy: “My drum beats for greater simplicity, a relaxed naturalness, more imagination, some invention and above all clothes that serve the modern activated woman who considers good design an adjunct to living with a certain joy and vitality.”  The second clipping shows a woman in a classic Chemise dress in a wool blend ($80). There is a matching leather sash to belt the dress.  Comes in Navy, Real Pink, Saddle, Black, or Redwing Red.  The third clipping is another dress in cashmere.  It comes in two lengths: long and regular.  The long comes in Oriole Orange, Peony Pink, Sunflower Orange, and Bonnie Blue, and costs $175.  The regular lenght comes in Natural, Sunflower Yellow, Oriole Orange, Mint Green, Bonnie Blue, and Ivory, and costs $165.  The fourth clipping shows Bonnie Cashin’s double handle bag, Zipper Closing at the top and an extra snap closing compartment on the side. Gloved tanned genuine leather in Black, Saddle, Putty, Red,White, or Navy ($52).  The fifth clipping shows an ankle-length cashmere dress available in long or regular length.  The long dress ($160) and comes in Oriole Orange, Peony Pink, or Bonnie Blue.  The regular length ($150) comes in Peony Pink, Sunflower Yellow, or Bonnie Blue.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: cardigans|~|purses (ladies' accessories)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|dresses (garments)--1970-1980|~|leather|~|shoulder bags|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 33a
AltTitle.other: Gene Burton
Description.note: Five clippings, all appear to be from same source (catalog fo Gene Burton?).  The first is a maxiskirt dress, made in Scotland of the world’s finest cashmere. Fully fashioned, V neck and figure flattering ribbing at waist and sleeve. The dress comes in long and regular length.  The long dress is $175 and available in the following colors: Mint Green, Peony Pink, Sunflower Yellow, or Bonnie Blue.  The regular length is available in Beige, Aqua, Oriole Orange, or Bonnie Blue and costs $165.  The second clipping shows Bonnie Cashin’s gloved tanned genuine leather handbag. It has a shoulder strap, and inside zipper compartment.  It is available in Black, Putty, Saddle, Rust, Navy or Red and costs $44.  The third clipping shows a classic envelope shoulder bag in glove tanned leather with a brass clip.  It costs $42 and comes in red, navy saddle tan, white, or black.  There is also a leather handbag with shoulder straps.  Between two brass framed sections is an ample center compartment.  It comes in red, navy, saddle tan, white, or black and costs $32.  The fourth clipping shows Bonnie Cashin cashmere Sweater Jacket made of cashmere. Grosgrain ribbon outline inside front and across bottom for shaping. Beautiful small brass buttons. Available in Bonnie Blue, Sunflower Yellow, Mint Green, Oriole Orange, White, Peony Pink, Black, Natural, Red.  Costs $105.  The fifth clipping shows a Kid Skin Genuine leather short coat.  It costs $200 and is available in White, Sand, Redwing Red, Navy, Lemon Yellow or Sandstone.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 33b
AltTitle.other: On top of the weather, our Bonnie Cashin makes sunshine news come rain or shine!|~|The big, wide, wonderful whirl of Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin at Lord & Taylor.  There is a drawing of a woman in a black-oakwood-white houndstooth checked wool with black leather collar, buckled closing, and piping coat.  It costs $300.  The secon clipping (The Plain Dealer, March 2, 1976) is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin at Halle's.  There is a drawing of a woman in a cotton poplin coat that comes in beige turf or pheasant blue.  It costs $200.

Title: Page 34a
AltTitle.other: Springtime is playtime along Seventh Avenue
Description.note: One clipping.  From The New York Times, November 11, 1975.  This article discusses the Springtime designs of various designers.  Cashin's suede two-piece dress / shirt and skirt.  Bracketed in pen is a section in the article about Cashin.  Bonnie Cashin is discussed as a "law unto herself" and her intriguingly named colors are also noted (examples: "papaya" and "lovebird").

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 39a
AltTitle.other: Here's the Bonnie Cashin handbag principle: ample space, shoulder room, and a beautiful shape that holds up through some hard knocks
Description.note: One clipping.  From The New York Times, August 29, 1976.  Advertisement for Bonnie Cashin handbags at Saks Fifth Avenue.  According to the text, Cashin handbags are for those who "go about life with gusto."  There is also an image of a woman looking slightly back over her shoulder.  She wears a long sweater and has a Cashin handbag resting on her back, slung over her shoulder.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: scarves (costume accessories)|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|tweed|~|knickerbockers|~|plaids|~|shirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 39b
AltTitle.other: Plaids for Fall|~|A style of old is new again
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first clipping is from The New York Times, September 12, 1976.  This article discusses bloused pants or "bloomers".  There is a photograph of Cashin's daytime bloomers, underneath a large coat with a hood.  The article discusses how to wear these bloomers.  A dress-up version by Stavropoulos is also shown.  The second clipping has handwritten above "Wash. Star" Washington Star but there is no date.  This clipping shows two Cashin plaid wool coats made of rugged Irish tweed with a detachable "fling" scarf with leather tracery on the coat.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|suits (main garments)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|dresses (garments)|~|trousers|~|coats (garments)|~|plaids|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 40a
AltTitle.other: Cashin clothes feature color variety|~|Pick a country... any country...|~|Lipmans
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is from the Daily News, May 7, 1976.  Brief article discussing the ethnic and international influences on American fashion.  Underlined and bracketed in red pen is a section about Bonnie Cashin.  There is a photograph of a woman in a huge bias-cut plaid cape made of Irish fabric.  The second clipping is from The Sunday Oregonian, August 8, 1976.  It is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin for Philip Sills at Lipmans.  There is a photograph of a woman in a classic-shape doublefaced fabric coat in grey and camel color piped in camel leather.  It costs $300.  The third clipping is also The Sunday Oregonian, October 3, 1976.  There are two photographs.  One shows Bonnie Cashin's great cape in one-size-fits-all ties at the shirred neckline with leather thongs, and is piped in leather.  Beneath it is a dress in wool jersey with a leather trim.  It comes in a variety of colors such as aubergine, paprika, and earth tones.  The other photograph is a pantsuit with bold plaid pants and a velvety suede jacket with plaid lining.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|suits (main garments)|~|skirts (garments)|~|shawls |~|jackets (garments)|~|cashmere (wool)|~|capes (outerwear)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|pullovers|~|hoods (headgear)|~|dresses (garments)|~|leather|~|trousers|~|cowl neck collar|~|plaids|~|maxiskirts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 40b
AltTitle.other: Design genius Cashin' in|~|Cashin styles, neither shocking nor faddish, 'come naturally'
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is a clipping from the Trend section of The Dallas Morning News, October 1, 1976.  The article deals with the quality of Cashin's designs and how she is not one to follow or care about trends.  There is a photograph of Cashin in a headcloth [wrap? hat?], a cowl-neck sweater, a shawl [poncho?] and pants.  She poses at Neiman-Marcus with models wearing fashions from her fall collection.  One wears a cashmere, leather, and plaid wool pants ensemble, and the other wears a long white cashmere dress with bias cut Scotch plaid poncho type cape.  The second clipping is from the Dallas Times Herald, September 30, 1976.  The article discusses Cashin's concept of layering inspired by the Chinese, as well as Cashin's distate for fads.  There is a photograph accompanying the article showing Cashin (in the same outfit as the first clipping) with two models.  One model wears a turtleneck, a white jacket, and a skirt, and the other model wears a plaid skirt suit and a hood.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 41a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin... in person!
Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten on bottom left of page is "Dallas Morning News  Sept. 28/76".  Advertisement for Neiman-Marcus.  Sketches of two Cashin fashions, as well as a close-up of the interior of a Cashin bag.  One woman wears a turtleneck dress, and a long plaid coat.  She also holds a bag.  The second woman wears a hood, a tabard [not totally sure], a coat, and a long skirt.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|ponchos|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|sweaters--1970-1980|~|trousers|~|shirts|~|headcloths (headgear)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 41b
AltTitle.other: Hitting the hot spots
Description.note: One clipping.  From September 17-24, 1976, source unknown.  A brief article discussing Cashin's news styles for the Knittery.  There are five accompanying drawings of women wearing the new styles.  The styles include: pull-on pants, a pull-on long skirt, a pull-on calf length skirt, a wrap top, a funnel top, the bubble top, and the poncho over all. Sketched here, some of the ways to put it all together: the beige bubble top and pants; the same pants and top with the white poncho; the poncho worn swung over one shoulder with the beige funnel top sweater; the funnel sweater and the long side-slit skirt; the wrap top and the shorter pull-on skirt.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: turtleneck sweaters|~|coats (garments)--1970-1980|~|suede|~|plaids|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 42a
AltTitle.other: Fashions downtown
Description.note: One clipping.  From the St. Paul Pioneer Press, September 8, 1976.  Handwritten in top right corner is "Theodores".  The article discusses the new coat department of a store called Theodore's.  There are three photograph of Cashin's coat.  The first shows a double faced wool pea coat with brass buttons done in red faced with camel.  The model also wears a hat, and pants.  The second photograph shows a turtleneck cashmere sweater under a suede jacket lined in the same pure wool as the plaid pants the model also wears. The third photograph shows a plaid drawstring waist Irish wool tweed coat, traced in leather with detachable scarf for headcovering, shoulder draping, carefree wrapping, and hand warming.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: cardigans|~|ponchos|~|cashmere (wool)|~|vests (garments)|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|purses (ladies' accessories)|~|mohair|~|trousers
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 42b
AltTitle.other: Release weekend
Description.note: Three clippings.  They all seem to be related.  The first clipping describes the outfit sketched in the second clipping.  This sketch shows a cotton sweater vest with a chin- warmer to raise, two hooded sweaters are in cashmere and furry mohair with front zip and leather tie belt, the pants are knit’ tucked into boots. And over all, a weightless brushed shetland wool poncho.  The third clipping describes a variety of Cashin's designs in terms of how they look in layered form.  The writer cautions that the layered look can look as delicate and elegant as a puff paste, or as heavy and fattening as a stack of country pancakes.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: headgear|~|turtleneck sweaters
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 43a
AltTitle.other: On the bias|~|After hours in California
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is from Stores, August 1976.  On the top right corner is handwritten "Aug. /76".  Cashin discusses an absolutely charming little restaurant in San Juan Capistrano called Las Buenas Amigas; a tiny little hole in the wall restaurant called Louise's Pantry in Palm Springs; and The Hungry Tiger which has awfully good seafood.  Cashin also notes that when she is in Los Angeles, she stays with friends in Beverly Hills.  She says that the real social group stays at home in California instead of going out.  There is an accompanying photograph of Cashin in a turtleneck sweater.  The second clipping is from the August - September 1976 issue of The Trade.  Handwritten on the bottom left is "The Trade - Aug. / Sept. /76".  This article is written by Cashin.  She discusses fabric and their sources.  She also discusses knitting, and knits.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design

Title: Page 43b
AltTitle.other: About our cover|~|Bonnie Cashin '76|~|Adventure...in the spirit of '76 from Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: Three clippings.  The first is the cover of The Independent, June 26, 1976.  There is a drawing of a woman in a Cashin suede warm up jacket and front pleat skirt.  She also wears a headcloth.  The second clipping is about the cover, describing the outfit on the cover.  The third clipping is from The Barn Shop Chanticleer.  There is a drawing of Cashin all purpose winter coat of double faced wool.  It is redwing on the outside and camel inside and costs $318.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: ponchos|~|turtleneck sweaters|~|pullovers|~|checker pattern|~|leather|~|trousers|~|jump suits|~|raincoats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 44a
AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin's not one for fantasy
Description.note: One clipping.  From the Toronto Globe + Mail (handwritten in top left).  "Sept. 24 '76" is also handwritten.  The article discusses Cashin's lack of desire to make fantasy clothes.  She finds them "too much trouble for active women-- women who lead interesting lives."  She designs clothes in terms of environment and "context-of-life situation."  Her clothes are praised as realistic.  There are two photographs accompanying the article.  One is an outfit that is layers of checks, leather, and rainproof poplin.  This outfit includes a poncho, a hood, a turtleneck sweater, and a checkered pullover.  The second photograph shows a jersey jumpsuit.

Description.note: One clipping.  Handwritten on the bottom right of the page is "Chattanooga News Free Press Aug. /76".  Advertisement for Cashin's coats at Lovemans.  There are three drawings of coats and jackets.

AltTitle.other: Bonnie Cashin for Sills: reflections on elegance|~|Bonnie Cashin... unsurpassed in fashion
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is an advertisement for The Addis Co. with handwritten in the bottom left corner "Syracuse - N.Y."  There is a drawing of two women in Cashin coats, one coat has a fur lined hood.  The second clipping is an advertisement for Halle's.  There is a drawing of a woman in a little slip of a dress in flowing wool jersey with leather trim, important pockets, and amazing convertible cowl.  It comes in sandstone, black, or dark brown and costs $100.

Title: Page 45b
AltTitle.other: Halle's|~|Picking cotton
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first is an advertisement for Bonnie Cashin for Sills fall collection at Halle's.  There is a drawing of a suede blazer suit with signature closing in oak.  The woman also wears a hat and a turtleneck sweater.  The second clipping is (handwritten:) from The Observer - London.  It is from August 22, 196.  Some glue (?) has shown through the paper.  This article discusses cotton fashions by various designers.  The accompanying photographs show outfits featuring designs by a variety of designers.  Cashin's cotton cowl-neck sweater is shown.

AltTitle.other: Wanted Bonnie Cashin
Description.note: One clipping.  There is a ripped out section of newspaper wanted ads on top of a piece of olive green canvas (?).  The ad reads "WANTED BONNIE CASHIN coats, capes, accessories.  Must be like new, and in perfect condition.  Write Bonnie Cashin, P.O Box 5566, Carmel."  The ad is circled in black and above the ad is written "WHO?!" and below "SOMEBODIE's [sic] CAPITILIZING [sic] ON CASHIN!"

Description.note: One clipping.  Paper above clipping says "Chicago, ILL. Southtown Economist" with a stamp reading "Aug 22 1978".  There is a photograph of a Bonnie Cashin capelet poplin Inverness raincoat with a Sherlock Holmes air and accented by a checked deerstalker cap.  The woman holds a magnifying glass to complete the Sherlock Holmes look.

Project Name: Cashin (Bonnie) Collection of Fashion, Theater and Film Costume Design
Subject: suits (main garments)|~|jackets (garments)|~|trousers|~|raincoats|~|hats
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Page 27a
AltTitle.other: New longer skirts will put buyers in market for coats, too|~|Bonnie Cashin signatures have lower price tags
Description.note: Two clippings.  The first clipping has a piece of paper above "Portland, Oreg. Oregonian" and stamped "Jun 24 1978".  The article discusses Fall coats.  There is a red bracket around the section about Bonnie Cashin weatherwear for Russ Taylor.  There is a photograph of a woman in an elasticized poplin rain jacket ("the bubble") and slim elasticized "Gringos" or weatherwear pants.  The woman also wears a rain hat that resembles a beret.  The second clipping has a piece of paper above reading "Pittsfield, Mass. Berkshire Eagle" and stamped is "Jul 28 1978".  The article discusses Cashin's designs, particularly her warm ponchos and coats, as well as her collections for The Knittery.  The practicality and simplicity of Cashin's designs are discussed.
